name: "We are with You" WAWY
description:
Struggling with Drug & Alcohol Addiction? We Are With You provide free and confidential Services, without judgement, to people over the age of 18 facing challenges with drugs & alcohol.

We Are With You are now offering a drop in session at Victor House fourth Thursday of each month, please contact Victor House to make an appointment.

organization.name: Victor House
organization.description:
Victor House Is a Safe Hub offering vital support to people who are homeless or at risk of homelessness. Victor House opens seven days a week, including Christmas Day 2-6pm and Boxing Day 8-10pm providing hot drinks  and donations of food are provided when available, essential support services are offered based upon, strength based conversations and care & support needs identified. 
Showering/laundry facilities are also available.

Night Provision is available and this is based on visitors completing a form daily - with support - from the team at Victor House in order for application to be considered based on priority need.

name: #TalkSuicide
description:
The Together service is here to support local people who have been bereaved by suicide across Hull, East Riding of Yorkshire, North East Lincolnshire and North Lincolnshire.

The new service, which has been funded by Humber, Coast and Vale Health and Care Partnership, is delivered locally by Hull and East Yorkshire Mind and North East Lincolnshire Mind. It offers free emotional and practical support to individuals of any age who have lost someone to suicide.

Support can include:

  • talking with an experienced bereavement worker
  • support creating memory boxes
  • funeral planning
  • attending inquests
  • help with financial matters

If you would like more information, please call Hull and East Yorkshire Mind / North East Lincolnshire Mind on Freephone 0800 1380990, local number 01482 240133 (between 8am – 8pm 7 days a week) or email info@heymind.org.uk. You can also text them on 07520 633447.

You are not alone, and there are people available to help.

organization.name: North East Lincolnshire Mind
organization.description:
Originally Grimsby and Cleethorpes District Mind, North East Lincolnshire Mind is located at Kent Street in Grimsby. As well as helping people to enhance their quality of life, we also support them to engage in meaningful activities within a community setting with social and emotional support. We help each person we work with to increase their independence and achieve the goals they set for themselves.

As a charity North East Lincolnshire Mind has an ambitious vision for the future in which we will not give up until everybody experiencing a mental health problem gets both support and respect.

name: Action Station
description:
If you’re over 16 in need of support to improve your prospects of finding work, currently unemployed or looking to progress your career we can help you track down the right options for you.

  • CV writing
  • Application form completion
  • Mock interviews
  • Help accessing traineeships and apprenticeships
  • Supported employment
  • Key worker support for eligible people through the Supported Employment Project.

For more information and to access the service, please email action.station@northlincs.gov.uk or call 01724 296969.

organization.name: Twin Tigers Martial Arts
organization.description:
PROVIDING QUALITY MARTIAL ARTS FOR OVER 15 YEARS
Since we opened in June 2006, we’ve seen seasons come and ago. Timid students transform into warriors, students becoming trainers and a whole lot of changes at our venue. But no matter who’s training or what we’ve had to train with, our goal has remained the same – to provide our community of Scunthorpe and North Lincolnshire with the finest Martial Arts education we can offer.

We are blessed to have an incredible team of dedicated instructors including Master grades in both our key martial arts.

At the core of the team Master Smith and wife Lisa Smith work to maintain the family values of the school. Although several of the instructors share the Smith surname it is only coincidence.

Most of our instructors joined Twin Tigers to follow their own path many years ago and have since decided to share the life skills and benefits they found with others.

Twin Tigers is dedicated to developing our students, through a martial arts education.

Our instruction team work tirelessly to get the best out of each student. We ensure that our student’s progression is earned, never given. No matter the skill level or ability, we tailor our student’s experiences to secure the best Martial Arts education possible, for children, adults and everyone in between, we have a class for you.

We believe not only do we have the best instruction team in the area, we also have the best facilities by far

organization.name: The Arc
organization.description:
We are a friendly well-being hub based in the heart of the Westcliff community and we’re part of Ongo, which means all profit we make is put back into the local community. 

Call into our cafe for a cuppa, find out about events and activities, rent a room, catch up with old friends, or meet new ones. We also have free wifi, a Post Office and loads more to get involved in.

There’s a whole range of support and training available here at The Arc. From our Employment Support Coaches and Housing Officers, to agencies we work with like Humberside Police, North Lindsey College and North Lincolnshire Council. So if you need training or support, come and speak to us.

name: Age UK Lindsey - Information and Advice
description:
Age UK Lindsey offers a free, impartial and confidential information and advice service for older people, their families and carers. We specialise in providing quality-assured, age-specific support to anyone over fifty living in East Lindsey, West Lindsey or North Lincolnshire.

Our advisers are trained to help you on the following topics:

  • Social care - such as finding and funding care at home or in a residential setting
  • Your income - including free benefits checks, help with applying for pension-age entitlements, and information about local or national grants
  • Your home - information on staying warm at home and adaptations to help maintain your wellbeing and independence
  • Local services - those provided by Age UK Lindsey and our partners across the region
  • Combating isolation - supporting you to enjoy an active later life and find the social interaction you need

How do I access the service?

The best way to get in touch with our I&A Service is by calling 01507 524242 (option 1). Our lines are open Monday-Friday 9am to 3pm but please be aware that we are often very busy and your call may be redirected to the Age UK national helpline or the answerphone. If they are not able to help you, they will take your details and you will be added to our call-back list. Alternatively, you can complete our service referral form, (see below), and your enquiry will be added to our database and call-back list. We aim to deal with all calls and requests within 3 working days.

You can also refer a family member, friend or (for healthcare professionals) your client, using either of the above methods.

https://www.ageuk.org.uk/lindsey/our-services/service-referral-form/

name: Alfie Moore: Radio Warm-up Show
description:
Cop-turned-comedian Alfie returns with a brand-new show ahead of recording his BBC Radio 4 comedy It’s a Fair Cop. The audience are sworn in as cops before Alfie shares a real-life scenario from his own casebook. He playfully challenges them to say what they would’ve done – with often unexpected and entertaining results. Policing decisions are easy in hindsight, aren’t they? Now you can experience the thrills, spills and laughter of making high-risk calls in the moment. Fair Cop: Live! is challenging, thought-provoking and fun. It’d be a crime to miss!

 “…offbeat, revealing and very funny” ***** – You Magazine

“Brilliantly funny, genuinely hilarious” – David Mitchell

“His charisma shines through as bright and colourful as a twirling blue light” – Times

4pm and 7.30pm

name: All Abilities Pilates Classes
description:
Our classes run in six-week blocks. Whether you are a complete beginner or someone who loves Pilates, our all abilities classes are perfect for you.


During the classes: 
-We will show you safe and effective exercises to mobilise your joints so you can move more freely
-We will show you specific exercises to strengthen your muscles, so your aches and pains start to ease.
You'll be shown quick exercises you can do in less than 5 minutes to avoid your muscles becoming tight and painful.

By the end of the sixth class you will be on your way to becoming stronger and feeling more confident in yourself. 

Can't make your usual class? Not to worry, you can book in to one of the other weekly sessions!

The six week blocks can be booked here, plus visit for full details of classes: https://app.acuityscheduling.com/catalog.php?owner=20729541&category=Pilates
pc_attendingAccess_additionalInfo:
Advanced bookings only 
Can’t make your usual session, you can attend any of our others (subject to space)

name: Ambassador Wellbeing
description:
Receiving a cancer diagnosis is difficult, so it’s important to know that there are therapies available that can help you manage both the condition and your experience of treatment.

Hypno-Oncology is a complementary therapy which utilises hypnosis and other psychological techniques to assist those going through the cancer journey.
A specially trained and accredited Hypno-Oncology Practitioner can provide you with psychological and emotional support, helping you through the period of diagnosis, treatment and beyond.

Hypno-Oncology Practitioners do not treat cancer or offer advice on treatment and is not a replacement for the treatment or advice given to you by your qualified medical and health professionals.

As a person living with Stage 4 cancer, my sessions with Deb have enhanced and helped my positivity immensely. Along with helping my immune system, her healing and relaxation techniques have aided my sleep patterns, general anxiety and coping mechanisms for hospital treatments, scans and results 

R. Brown  

What can Hypno-Oncology be used for?

Hypno-Oncology can be used for all aspects of the cancer journey including:

  • Anxiety, fear and worry – these are common emotions that can be worked with.
  • Phobias and fears – claustrophobia, needle fear/phobia and many other aspects of treatment
  • Pre/post surgery hypno-oncology could improve outlook and outcomes
  • Addressing treatment side effects such as nausea, fatigue, vertigo, taste issues, hot flushes, sleep issues
  • Help with pain control

Appointments are available face to face or online via Zoom if you would prefer.
pc_attendingAccess_additionalInfo: Online sessions are also available.

name: Amy Johnson: Last Flight Out
description:
Written and performed by Jenny Lockyer Directed by Vern Griffiths

Born in the year the Wright Brothers made their first flight and into an age where the romantic heights of flying captured her heart, Amy Johnson became the second woman in the world to qualify as a ground engineer and then, in 1930, the first woman to fly solo from England to Australia.

Amy lived her life for adventure and the future of aviation. In January 1941, at just 37 years old, Amy was killed while serving her country on a routine flight for the Air Transport Auxiliary.

In her short time this ‘lone girl flier’ achieved so much and while faced with challenges of all kinds.

We meet Amy in a world of memories, desires, wishes and ambitions. As we find out about her life we start to see how the pieces fit and the tools Amy used to bring her dreams to reality.

There will be a post-show Q&A.

This performance is part of our Members’ 241 Offer – please ask for details.

Tickets to be purchased from The Ropewalk.

name: Andys Man Club
description:
ANDYS MAN CLUB is a men’s suicide prevention charity, offering free-to-attend peer-to-peer support groups across the United Kingdom and online. We want to end the stigma surrounding men’s mental health and help men through the power of conversation.  We aim to achieve this through weekly, free-to-attend peer-to-peer support groups for men aged over 18. #ITSOKAYTOTALK

ANDYS MAN CLUB has over 120 free support groups nationwide, running every Monday from 7pm except bank holidays. In these groups, men can open up about the storms affecting their lives in a safe, judgement-free and non-clinical environment. Our clubs are designed to be free of pressure, there is no obligation for men to speak, they can simply listen if they wish.

With over 2800 men using our sessions every week, and an army of 900+ volunteers on board, the movement is continuing to grow week-by-week. We firmly believe in the power of talking and that #ItsOkayToTalk.

Established in 2016 by Elaine, Andy’s Mum, and Luke, Andy’s Brother-in-Law, the aim of the club is to provide men with a safe space where they feel comfortable to talk and open up about their experiences in a room free of judgment.

The sessions are on a drop-in basis and held on Mondays 7pm till 9pm (except Bank Holidays).

organization.name: New Beginnings
organization.description:
New Beginnings Personal Training and Wellness Facility offer the highest quality services and treatments for mind, body and wellness.


Our services are provided by highly qualified personal trainers who are experts in their field and hand selected by the New Beginning's owner and founder, Stacey Greenfield. 


Feeling good is a complex issue. Health is at the heart of it, but psychology has a role to play as well, and we need to have that feeling of looking good.


New Beginnings brings together a range of services for mind, body and wellness to help our clients be fit and well inside and out. The best way to great health is to look after the whole body, not just the physical aspects but also the mental issues as well; as the saying goes "Healthy Body, Healthy Mind".


Looking after your health as a whole package is so important, yet it is something that far too many people sadly neglect.  Our range of services has been put together in such a way that many of them complement each other.


Our fully equipped personal training studio allows clients to work out in comfort and privacy. In addition this allows clients to also benefit from the expert advice of our personal trainers either with one-to-one support based on their individual goals or small group classes such as yoga.


Our New Beginnings founder is also qualified in nutrition and is available to put together the best possible programme to assist with weight loss, fitness issues and helping to create a health body. For those clients who have issues with food, we can assist with this. Helping you to create a more positive and healthier person both on the outside and as well as on the inside can give you the real boost of confidence that can be invaluable in both a professional and personal capacity. 

From counselling to life coaching, our highly professional team can help you to overcome whatever it is that is preventing you from achieving your goals.

name: Archaeology and History Club
description:
North Lincolnshire Museum is inviting budding historians and archaeologists (aged 8-12 years old) to join our Archaeology and History Club.

Children will explore the world of archaeology, learn new skills and get hands on with artefacts. Sessions will be led by experienced members of our learning team and will be held one Saturday a month.

organization.name: North Lincolnshire Museum
organization.description:
Discover the history of North Lincolnshire at our free museum near the centre of Scunthorpe.

A visit to the Museum is a step back in time through fascinating hands-on displays. Learn about some of North Lincolnshire’s amazing objects and stories. Explore the geology, local history and archaeology galleries. Discover how that history has been shaped by the landscape. Families can visit Dudley’s Den, a dedicated Under 5s space.

With a changing programme of family friendly exhibitions and events for all ages. Families can join Dudley Bear and explore by taking part in fun filled activities and crafts. Learn about North Lincolnshire with trails, back packs and family explorer packs.

Admission is free.

name: Armed Forces & Veterans Breakfast Club
description:
Welcome to the Scunthorpe Breakfast Club, part of the growing network of Armed Forces & Veterans Breakfast Clubs in the UK and Worldwide.

We are a group of veterans and serving members of Her Majesty’s Armed Forces. There are no commitments or subs… just a great place to meet like-minded people for support, chat and banter … not forgetting a great breakfast.

When requesting to join, please check all your message inboxes for messages from one of the club admin team, and once you have joined the Facebook Group, please check the group for times, dates and any updates.

Attending we have Veterans of the Army, Royal Navy, Royal Air Force and Royal Marines… so if you want to return to the tribe, come along, join in the banter as long as you have a uniform service history, or association with such, and can cope with the sense of humour.  It really works because we all have a similar sense of humour, values and outlook on life.

Whilst we don’t mind friendly banter.…… abuse, bullying and or harassment will not be tolerated. Anyone found harassing/bullying will be deleted from the Facebook Group, blocked, and will not be welcome at the club meetings, so please enjoy yourself and if you experience any issues, please don’t air it on the Facebook group; simply contact a member of the admin team for help and advice.

Spread the word and enjoy!

email : bwalters2414@gmail.com

tel : 07528681716

Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/groups/northlincsbreakfastclub/

organization.name: Armed Forces & Veterans Breakfast Clubs
organization.description: Welcome to the Official Armed Forces Veterans and Breakfast clubs.

name: Art Club
description:
Our art club is a really friendly group.

We welcome everyone from beginners to experienced painters.

Maybe you want to get better at what you paint, maybe you are just thinking about starting out...

Whatever your ability, come along and join in.  

You can spend three hours or as long or as little as you want working on your piece.

Gain tips from each other and get some ideas about ways to paint. 

It's a friendly relaxed space to take some time to create.

Our members paint with anything from pastels and watercolours to charcoals and acrylics. 

Whatever you want to bring, just come along and sit and enjoy creating.

We’re a friendly group and love to share ideas and coffees inbetween! 

See https://www.kirtoninlindsey.com/artclub for contact details

description:
Our Art club every Monday is a group of artistic people who come along to share their work with others.  Some paint, some do chalk paintings, some do wood burning pyrography.  There is no formal 'teaching' at this club, just bring along whatever type of art work you enjoy doing and work on it alongside other like minded people for a chat.

The group costs £2 per week.

This is a club for members of Central Community Centre, however you are free to come and try the group for a couple of weeks before you sign up to be a member.  Membership only costs £3 to join and then £2 per year after that. 

Membership entitles you to reduced group fees and reduced price on some trips and events.

name: Art Club
description: We are a friendly, creative group of people with a common interest – a love of painting and drawing in the medium of your choice. We meet twice per week on Tuesday Evening and Wednesday morning. Generally these are untutored sessions although we do arrange for professionals to deliver workshops on topics of interest throughout the year. Where needed, members are always willing to share advice and encouragement. Why not come along for a free session to meet the group before committing to join?

organization.name: Scunthorpe Museum Society Art Group
organization.description: We are a very friendly and informal group meeting twice per week. All sessions are free-painting, untutored. Artists of all abilities are welcome and they are encouraged to paint in their favourite medium, while also giving them the opportunity to try something different. This is achieved by one-to-one help, internal workshops and more formal workshops by professional artists. We have a huge library of reference books and a quantity of art materials for members to access. Two major exhibitions are held each year, plus one-day pop-up exhibitions, where members can sell their work.

name: Art Club
description: Free Arts and Crafts sessions for Children aged 8+ with a different theme every month.

organization.name: 20-21 Visual Arts Centre
organization.description:
About 20-21
Welcome to 20-21 Visual Arts Centre
The entrance to 20-21 Visual Arts Centre
20-21 Visual Arts Centre is housed in the former St. John’s Church building in Church Square, Scunthorpe. Since the gallery’s doors first opened in 2001 we have developed a reputation for offering a varied and exciting exhibition programme of contemporary art, craft and design.  We show around 20 exhibitions per year, across six exhibition spaces, and aim to be as ambitious and creatively diverse.  As well as bringing arts and culture to the local community, we aim to exhibit art by groups that are traditionally under represented in mainstream galleries.

Encompassing a wide range of media, subjects and artistic approaches, we present a mixture of in-house curated exhibitions, touring shows and exhibitions developed in partnership with fellow creative organisations.  We also produce and deliver our own touring exhibitions to other galleries nationally, and offer an extensive education programme for all ages and abilities.

We’re an Arts Council England [National Portfolio Organisation (NPO] which means funding thanks to tax payers and National Lottery players plays a huge part in supporting our work.

name: Art Therapy
description:
WHAT IS ART THERAPY?

Art Therapy is a form of psychotherapy that uses art materials and images to help with communication.

We explore the way you create, what you make and your changing moods and behaviour.   When we are struggling to express how we truly feel inside, the creative process can help identify what is going on.  Images you create are like signposts on how you deal with the world.  It is sometimes much more comfortable to see how you feel and talk about the images.

Depending on your needs you will be offered up to six therapy sessions to assess if art therapy is for you.  Your experiences will then be reviewed with you and any carers involved to explore if the therapy was useful.  A further plan will be discussed and agreed if appropriate.  Art therapy remains voluntary and you could leave if you feel uncomfortable at any time.  At the end of therapy you can choose if you want to take your art work home.

You do not need any special skills to take part.  Art therapy can be used with individuals or groups.  We will cater for any sensory difficulties.  Children or adults.  If you have no verbal communication skills our therapists have experience with symbols and makaton, however very often the images and the way you create can communicate for you.

What We Do:

  • Transitional work
  • Trauma
  • Bereavement or loss
  • Anxiety
  • Psychological incontinence
  • Behaviour change
  • Stress Management
  • Relaxation
  • Anger
  • Lifestyle planning or PCP support
  • Autistic spectrum
  • Aspergers support
  • Difficulties with autistic spectrum
  • Dementia
  • Short assessments or longer term therapy
  • Staff teambuilding and supervision
  • Free taster sessions

We can help find alternative ways to express your feelings in an environment you find familiar and safe. This could be your own home in the Humber area, or a place in which you are familiar. We are flexible and will discuss the meeting environment on a client by client basis.  

Funded group sessions are available on a Friday 1.30pm - 3pm in Immingham. 

These sessions only run during Term Time.

organization.name: Creative Futures Art Therapy and Hypnotherapy
organization.description: Jayne Gayle has over 7 years’ experience as an art psychotherapist and over 20 years’ experience as a community learning disability nurse (BSc, RNLD) and has worked in residential and community care for many years. She is qualified with the Health Professions Council (HPC) and holds a master’s degree in art psychotherapy. Jayne travels all across the Humber, visiting schools with children that have attachment difficulties or disabilities – helping them express how they feel using creativity as a means of communication and self-expression.

name: ASD Support Group
description: An opportunity to meet new people, talk and share experiences with other adults that have the same or similar neuro-divergent diagnoses in a safe place.

organization.name: Cloverleaf Advocacy
organization.description:
Everyone has the right to speak up for themselves, especially when it's about their health, care and wellbeing.

 

Not everyone can do this easily - so that's where we come in. We give people a voice when they find it difficult to express their views, but more than that - we make sure that decisions about them are not made without them.

 

Cloverleaf Advocacy is an independent charity, and all our services are free and confidential for those who need us. We know our stuff too. We've been around for 25 years and have a team of more than 100 highly-trained advocates available to help people across the North of England. Although we're not part of the NHS or social care services, we do understand how they work.

 

We can help people to:

 

Find information
Understand and uphold their rights
Consider their options
Get the support they need
Speak up about the issues that matter to them

You don't need to have any issues or concerns to access the group but if you do we will try our best to help you or signpost you to the people who will provide the right support.

name: Ashby Community Hub
description:
Our community hubs

Our community hubs are based throughout North Lincolnshire. They make it easier for residents to access information, advice and support, and take part in activities to improve their health and wellbeing.

The hub spaces are open to everyone. They are a central point in the community with support and activities for all – young and old.

Aim of the hubs

The aim of the hubs is to:

  • improve health and wellbeing and outcomes for local people
  • develop skills and employability for residents, with a clear path to skilled jobs
  • create employment and volunteering opportunities
  • reduce social isolation by connecting residents to activities and services in the community
  • provide information, advice and guidance to local people based on individual need.

The offer in the hubs is built around the five steps to wellbeing. Easy-to-access programmes such as physical activity, social action, volunteering, health and wellbeing, employability and more are available. These activities enable people to maintain their independence, improve their health and wellbeing and develop a range of skills.

Direct help, advice and guidance is provided to meet the needs of residents and enable them to access the support and information they need to live safe, well, prosperous and connected lives.

Hub programmes

Examples of what is available to residents through the hubs programme includes:

  • bespoke IT training sessions to enable residents to take advantage of the social and economic benefits of being online
  • health checks for eligible residents as well as a range of specialist surgeries at certain times throughout the week
  • adult education and family learning sessions
  • general advice and support on council and community services
  • physical activity sessions to enable residents to get more active
  • health sessions around common medical conditions such as cardio-vascular disease and rehabilitation programme for people with chronic joint pain
  • social wellbeing activities that bring the community together such as healthy eating sessions, book clubs and knit and natter sessions.
  • a range of activities for children and young people which support wellbeing, including clubs and school holiday activities.

Facilities within the hub spaces include sport and leisure facilities, public libraries, digital technology, lifelong learning facilities, community kitchens and much more.

The flexible spaces are intended to support a range of community-led activity provided for by a range of organisations across public and voluntary sectors, who can provide additional health and wellbeing support. By working through these integrated approaches, members of the community receive joined up, quality, consistent information and support.

Community Hubs are located across North Lincolnshire within central and accessible locations in:

  • Ashby
  • Barton
  • Brigg
  • Crowle
  • Epworth
  • Riddings
  • Scunthorpe

To find the address of your local hub see the libraries and community hubs page

If you are feeling lonely or isolated, then please feel free to contact your local community hub on the phone numbers below. Or just drop in and say hello. You will always be given a warm welcome.

Contact

  • Barton and Winterton –01724 296808
  • Brigg  – 01724 296776
  • Scunthorpe – 01724 860161
  • Epworth – 01724 296870
  • Crowle –07825 901679

organization.name: North Lincolnshire Community Hubs
organization.description:
North Lincolnshire Council connects residents with their communities through a network of locality-based community hubs enabling independence and wellbeing. 
The Community Hubs support residents by providing a safe environment to access information, activities, skills and services, and by providing the tools to enhance personal knowledge, confidence and a sense of belonging.  
The majority of North Lincolnshire residents live within a 15 minute drive of their local community hub. Hubs are located in each of the following locations Scunthorpe, Brigg, Barton, Crowle, Epworth, Ashby & Riddings.

name: Athletics and Running Club
description:
Barton & District Athletic Club (BADAC) is a Club that has flourished enormously over the past 5 years due to the hard work and commitment of its volunteers. Our Club Motto is “From beginners to winners, small and tall, track, field and road – we do it all!”

We are a friendly, inclusive and forward-thinking Club based in Barton-upon-Humber, North Lincolnshire.

BADAC offers Juniors (8 to 10 years) and Youths (11 to 17 years), of all abilities, the chance to participate in athletics. Juniors and Youths train on a Thursday evening at Baysgarth School in Barton.

We also offer a Senior (over 18s) Road Running section which caters for all abilities from Couch to 5K to Marathon and Ultra Runners.

name: Autism Spectrum Education Team
description:
Our aim is to support and enable children and young people with social communication and interaction challenges and those on the Autism Spectrum to:

  • have equal access to every part of education
  • achieve their full potential in school and in the wider world
  • avoid being disadvantaged in society by their individual perspectives and experiences of the world
  • benefit from schools and settings that understand the impact of social communication and interaction challenges and Autism on children and young people and help them to learn in the best way for them.

For further information please visit the SEND Local Offer website - ​​​​​​​SEND Local Offer | Autism Spectrum Education Team (ASET) - SEND Local Offer (northlincs.gov.uk)

Our purpose

name: Autistica
description:
Autistica is the UK’s leading autism research and campaigning charity. Our mission is to create breakthroughs that enable autistic people to live happier, healthier, longer lives. We do this by funding research, shaping policy and working with autistic people to make more of a difference.

We were founded in 2004 by entrepreneur and philanthropist Dame Stephanie Shirley CH, whose son Giles was autistic.

Our 2030 goals

Based on your priorities, our 2030 Goals represent the change we want to see in the world. Combined with your support, we believe we are in a prime and unique position to help realise these visionary and ambitious goals, which will help us achieve our mission to see all autistic people live happier, healthier, longer lives.

Together we can create the change we want to see in the world, and that change starts now.

Visit the Autistica website for more information. 

Please note that we are a research charity. If you need support or need to know more about issues like diagnosis or local services, please call the National Autistic Society’s helpline on 0808 800 4104.

organization.name: Autistica
organization.description:
We are the UK’s leading autism research and campaigning charity. Our mission is to create breakthroughs that enable all autistic people to live happier, healthier, longer lives. We do this by funding research, shaping policy and working with autistic people to make more of a difference.

We know that every autistic person is different. And we know that autism comes with both strengths and challenges.

But there’s lots we don’t know.

Research is the best way to improve understanding, find new ways to support people and families, and change lives for the better.

We are making more of a difference by
Funding, shaping and growing research across the UK
Developing new therapies
Campaigning for better services and shaping national policy
Sharing evidence-based tools, resources and information

Suitable for babies aged 8+ weeks to six months. Term time class.

name: Baby Massage
description:
A wonderful bonding session for parents/guardian and baby. Using lovingly rhythmic strokes to areas of babies’ body, massage offers a wonderful experience and special time to communicate with baby. Benefits include reduced crying, longer sleep, relaxation, relief from pain and discomfort and aids development of body awareness and coordination. These sessions are health led by a Health Visitor.

Suitable for new born until around six months of age. Courses run in four week blocks. (Epworth course will now run at the new Live Well Isle of Axholme, formally known as Epworth Leisure Centre).

For more information or to book onto this session please contact the Family Hubs on 01724 296500 option 1 or family.hubs@northlincs.gov.uk

Please provide your full name, child's name and date of birth and a contact number.

name: Baby sensory classes in Scunthorpe
description:
Our Baby Sensory classes in Scunthorpe offer a warm and inviting environment where parents and their little ones can embark on a magical journey of sensory exploration and discovery. From gentle music and soothing textures to vibrant visuals and interactive play, each session is carefully curated to provide a rich variety of sensory stimulation.

Our award-winning baby sensory classes are led by experts, ensuring a stimulating experience where each week differs from the last. Suitable for babies 0-13 months, we believe in the power of sensory experiences to lay the foundation for a lifetime of learning and growth and are all designed to captivate your baby's interest and support their cognitive, social, and emotional development.  Please book in advance, term time blocks so price may vary depending on weeks included.

name: Bar Bonby
description:
Friday night usage of Bonby Village Hall for people to come together socially. There is no charge but people leave a financial donation as contribution to the Village Hall Committee's funds to keep this lovely building open and accessible.

It is run on a bring your own drink and nibbles, enjoy the company of others for a couple of hours on a Friday evening. Cans and bottles can be taken home afterwards for recycling.

Once a month a Quiz night is held. People join a table and join with other villagers. It is aimed as a fun evening not to be taken too seriously with the winning team being awarded a tin of sweets which are usually shared with everyone attending.

Coffee & Tea is also available at the counter.

name: Barton Inclusive Football Club
description:
Barton Inclusive FC is a community football club, with the ambition to provide 'Football for All' within Barton-upon-Humber and the surrounding areas.

We are an England Accredited football club, with qualified FA coaches.

We run the following sessions on the 3g pitch at Baysgarth School:

Monday 7pm-8pm - Inclusive Football - This session is for adults 16+ with additional needs or anyone living with a long term health condition

Monday 8pm-9pm - Walking Football - This is a open to anyone aged 50+ and all abilities welcome, including anyone with a previous injury or condition such as hip or knee replacement 

Wednesday 7pm-8pm - Women's Walking Football - suitable for females 18+. All abilities welcome. 

Wednesday 7pm -8pm - Women's Inclusive Football - Session aimed at females aged 16+ living with additional needs or long term health condition

For more information please contact via the details above.

name: Barton upon Humber Market
description:
The Barton Market is a monthly market held in the Market Place and the Butchery and Corn Exchange car park areas from 8.30am - 1.30pm. It is our aim is to support local small businesses in and around the Barton upon Humber area. Most of our small businesses are local makers of their own produce.

We have wax melts, bath and body products, bath bombs, wrought iron garden art, baked goods including brownies, bread, Indian food, hot food, locally farmed fresh meat, plant stalls and much much more.

Refreshments are available from the Barton Evangelical Church.

name: Baysgarth Park parkrun
description:
parkrun is a free, community event where you can walk, jog, run, volunteer or spectate the 5k every Saturday morning at 9am.

parkrun is positive, welcoming and inclusive, there is no time limit and no-one finishes last.  Everyone is welcome.

organization.name: Baysgarth Park parkrun
organization.description:
What is Baysgarth Park parkrun?
A free, fun, and friendly weekly 5k community event. Walk, jog, run, volunteer or spectate – it's up to you!

When is it?
Every Saturday at 9:00am.

Where is it?
The event takes place at Baysgarth Park, 60 Brigg Road, Barton-upon-Humber, DN18 6AH. See Course page for more details.

What does it cost to join in?
Nothing - it's free! but please register before you first come along. Only ever register with parkrun once and don't forget to bring a scannable copy of your barcode (request a reminder). If you forget it, you won't get a time.

How fast do I have to be?
We all take part for our own enjoyment. Please come along and join in whatever your pace!

name: BEAT Eating Disorders
description:
About eating disorders

Around 1.25 million people in the UK suffer from these illnesses, many in secret. They are of all ages, genders and backgrounds – eating disorders do not discriminate. Eating disorders include bulimia, binge eating disorder, avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder (ARFID), other specified feeding or eating disorder (OSFED), and anorexia, which tragically has the highest mortality rate of any mental illness, though all eating disorders can be deadly. While this is the worst-case scenario, there are many ways in which eating disorders severely affect the quality of life of both those suffering and those who care about them. They steal childhoods, devastate relationships and pull families apart. But, with the right treatment and support, recovery is possible.

What we do

Our national Helpline exists to encourage and empower people to get help quickly, because we know the sooner someone starts treatment, the greater their chance of recovery. People can contact us online or by phone 365 days a year. We listen to them, help them to understand the illness, and support them to take positive steps towards recovery. We also support family and friends, equipping them with essential skills and advice, so they can help their loved ones recover whilst also looking after their own mental health. And we campaign to increase knowledge among healthcare and other relevant professionals, and for better funding for high-quality treatment, so that when people are brave enough to take vital steps towards recovery, the right help is available to them.

The work we do means that every year lives are saved, families are kept together, and people are able to live free of eating disorders.

Our Values

We share the vision of an end to the pain and suffering caused by eating disorders. We are inspired by the people we serve, by the difference we can make, and by our commitment to each other.

Get in touch using the contact details listed or alternatively click here for full information on support available: Get information and support - Beat (beateatingdisorders.org.uk)

Our Helplines are open from 3pm– 8pm, 7 days a week, 365 days a year (366 in a leap year!)

Sometimes our lines are busy. If you can't get through immediately, please do try again or try our one-to-one web chat or send us an email.

If you are in need of urgent help or medical advice for yourself or someone else please contact 999 or the Samaritans on 116 123 if you or someone else is in immediate danger. If you are looking for medical advice contact your GP or 111.

Beat provides Helplines for people of all ages, offering support and information about eating disorders no matter where you are in your journey. These Helplines are free to call from all phones.

organization.name: BEAT
organization.description:
OUR MISSION
We are the UK’s eating disorder charity. Founded in 1989 as the Eating Disorders Association, our mission is to end the pain and suffering caused by eating disorders.

Beat has a board of Trustees who are the Directors of the Company. They are responsible for the overall direction, policies and strategy of Beat. The majority have personal experience of eating disorders as parents, family members or sufferers themselves.

name: Bell Ringing
description:
Change ringing is a style of church bell ringing started in England around the end of the sixteenth century.

Because of constraints imposed by the physics of swinging bells, tunes are not played. Instead, the bells are rung in ever changing patterns to a steady rhythm.

Change ringing, remains as widely practiced today as at any time in the past, and continues to evolve.

The largest concentration of interest remains in England, which is home to over 95% of the world's bells hung for change ringing, with many of the remainder in other parts of the UK. However, there are small pockets in other parts of the world, mostly, though not exclusively, former British colonies.

Please note bell ringing occurs at St Andrew's Church, Kirton in Lindsey, and is strictly by appointment and availability only.

name: Bella Gaffney
description:
Bella Gaffney (of The Magpies) is a folk troubadour whose music seamlessly weaves together original compositions and traditional tunes from both British folk and Americana traditions. Winner of the prestigious 2016 Celtic Connections Danny Kyle Award, Bella is celebrated for her folk-inspired songwriting and unique arrangements of traditional pieces.

In 2023, Bella released her latest album, ‘Reflections,’ which beautifully captures the essence of connections formed during the lockdown period. Her singles, ‘Fair and Tender Ladies’ and ‘Blood in the Earth,‘ featuring duets with Sam Kelly and Leesa Gentz (Hussy Hicks), received widespread acclaim and BBC radio airplay.

Apart from her solo endeavors, Bella is a vital member of the folk band The Magpies, lauded as ‘effervescent’ by The Sunday Times. The Magpies have garnered national and international recognition, including a live session on BBC Radio 2 and hosting an annual sold-out festival.


£14/£16 OTD

name: Beyond the Noise Counselling Services
description:
What Is Person-Centred Counselling?

Given the right conditions, a person can reach their full potential and become their true self.

A person-centred counsellor will help you to become more self-aware and achieve greater independence. You’ll be encouraged to bring your own issues to the session – the counselling is led by you and not directed by me.

You will be treated as the expert on yourself, as no-one else knows exactly what it’s like to be you.

Introductory sessions last for 90 minutes, subsequent sessions last for 55 minutes.   We will cover introductions and go through an initial assessment in the introductory session.

How often and how many sessions you will have depends on your individual circumstances, and will be agreed between us.

You’ll get the best results if you’re open and honest and say how you’re really feeling.

Sessions are based in Bottesford, Scunthorpe. Please call to discuss further and book a session.

Put simply, our vision is to support our local community and as followers of Jesus, grow together, in faith, in hope and in love.

name: Boogie Bounce
description:
Boogie Bounce

This is a fitness class on a mini trampoline with a handle. The trampoline takes 80% of the impact so it is kind to your joints. The class is done to some great music and is a fun way to work out. There are many benefits to these classes such as there is an average calorie burn in a 45 minute class of between 450 to 600.  Benefits include:

  • Improved balance, coordination and posture
  • Enhanced digestion
  • Improved metabolism
  • Lower blood pressure
  • Arthritis management
  • Supports the pelvic floor

and much more!

Please note that because of the number of trampolines available at each venue classes have to be booked through the Gymcatch app on the link provided and that there is a 48 hour cancellation period.

organization.name: Sue Wakefield Fitness
organization.description:
I have been teaching different classes at many different gyms, fitness centres and other venues for over 35 years now. I started fitness quite late on in life doing the initial training with my daughter as she didn’t want to do it on her own and from then on I was hooked and have never looked back.

Well firstly my participants are my priority and I understand that to enjoy a class you need to feel welcome and safe; you need to know its ok if the class is moving in one direction and you’re going in the other its fine. Everybody does it so you’re not the first and won’t be the last.

I think my classes have been popular for so many years is because they are fun, hey even I go wrong but we can laugh about it.

Its important you work at a level that feels good for you and you are in an environment that allows this.

I know there are barriers to fitness for many people but hopefully the classes can help remove some of those for you and leave you feeling empowered and crush any doubts you may had about yourself and abilities.

name: Bowling Club
description:
Scunthorpe Bowls Club was established in 1919 and has been at its current location since 1936. Whether you are new to bowls, or have played before we are here to help you.  The outdoor season runs from late April until mid September.  Sets of bowls are available to borrow, all you need is a pair of flat soled shoes.  Members can play in local leagues or play socially with friends. 

Annual Membership is currently £35 plus a one off joining fee of £5.  For new and less experienced bowlers, we have a fully qualified coach who is available for coaching sessions.  

We're not only a Bowls Club as we run social events throughout the year, such as quizzes and - new for 2024 - a Murder Mystery Event. Our grounds and venue are wheelchair accessible.

We have recently launched our website - www.scunthorpebowlsclub.com and we have a Facebook page too.

We look forward to welcoming you to our friendly club. 

Please contact for more information during the times stated or revisit here for session dates and times.

description:
We represent 25 clubs across North Lincolnshire (and slightly beyond) who play outdoor bowls between April and September. This covers Scunthorpe and District Bowls Leagues (5 leagues) , North Lincolnshire Trips leagues ( 5 leagues) and Tuesday afternoon Trips league.

You can play socially at one of the many sessions that clubs have during the season (you don't have to be a member) or you can play in one of the many leagues which cover a wide range of abilities (in which case you do need to be a member). Membership costs vary from club to club but are generally around £40.

If you want to just go along to the open sessions then it is around £2 if you are not a member. As well as that, many clubs hold open days at the beginning of the season where you can go along and try without any commitment or cost, you just need some flat shoes.

The website is at sdbl.uk and we are on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/groups/317021333815361/. If you would like more information then contact Mark at bowlsnorthlincs@gmail.com


Please note session times and dates vary. Please get in touch to find out when session are running in your local league.

name: Brave Rival
description:
Five years on and Brave Rival are the fast-rising, rip-roaring, rock and blues juggernaut ready to take their place in the upper echelons of British Rock Hierarchy.

Since their inception in 2019, Portsmouth based Brave Rival have delighted fans and critics alike with their modern take on classic rock vibes. This culminated in the release of their 2022’s debut ‘Life’s Machine’ featuring  a dozen nuggets of sharp melody and emotive playing, topped off by the delightful, hypnotising interplay of co-vocalists Chloe Josephine and Lindsey Bonnick. ‘Life’s Machine’ drew strong praise across the board,  also bringing the group (completed by guitarist Ed ‘the Shred’ Clarke, bassist Billy Dedman and drummer Donna Peters) to the attention of the American guitar superstar Joe Bonamassa, who rated them among his “favourite discoveries” of that year.

Across North Lincolnshire there are cafes, restaurants, shops and other businesses that are happy to welcome breastfeeding families on their premises. Many have joined the Breastfeeding Welcome Here Scheme and have agreed that:

  • breastfeeding is acceptable in all areas open to the general public
  • a mother who is breastfeeding in an area open to the general public will not be asked to move to another area or stop breastfeeding
  • all staff members will be aware of the scheme and be supportive of breastfeeding mums
  • they will display the 'Breastfeeding Welcome Here' scheme window sticker.

The list of Breastfeeding Welcome Here Scheme members is regularly updated. If you don’t see any businesses listed in your area at this time, please search again in the future. You can also help by calling and asking us to register them.

Across North Lincolnshire there are cafes, restaurants, shops and other businesses that are happy to welcome breastfeeding families on their premises. Many have joined the Breastfeeding Welcome Here Scheme and have agreed that:

name: Breath Coaching
description:
This is a 4 week course that teaches you breathing techniques that can help to manage your nervous system.

This course will teach you specific techniques for your needs and help you to build you own daily practice so that you use these techniques on a regular basis and especially when you need them most.

It starts with a short discovery call to find out more and to explore whether this is a course for you.  Simply contact me to arrange this session.  Then if suitable we book 4 weekly sessions of 30 minutes that you can access 1-1 on zoom from your home, place of work or where ever suits you best.  As long as you have a good connection.

You will also be given recordings to guide you through each of the breath techniques given.

1-1 breath coaching to help manage stress and anxieties. 

Appointments available on a Wednesday evening, all day Thursday or possible weekend appointments.
pc_attendingAccess_additionalInfo: Email to book a 10 minute discovery call and see how this may benefit you

organization.name: Mindful Connections
organization.description:
Wellbeing Days | Retreats | Nature Immersions
Often our Lives are so busy and so full trying to find the time for ourselves can become too hard.

Before we know it - we are at discord with ourselves, lost direction, feeling in a rut of a mundane, un-nourishing and energy zapping existence.
We have lost ourselves. We are no longer aligned to our values and even when we start to notice this; it just seems to create even more discord and our inner critic has a field day!
Sometimes just stepping completely away from the normality of life, gives us the chance to just pause and breathe.
It gives us the opportunity to reflect and restore.
To reconnect to what is important and of value in our lives.
The added bonus is that these nourishing days, always seem to attract like minded souls.
People who you can really connect and converse with deeply and with intention.

Each wellbeing day has a different offering.
Single day immersions  invite you to experience a deeper connection with nature and your true nature.

Weekends are about real time for you. They are a true opportunity to pause, reflect and connect.
Our community connections that are forged, often  last long after the retreat ends and sometimes life long friendships.

name: Brigg and District Gardening Club
description:
Small, friendly gardening club based in Brigg. We meet seven times a year to discuss gardening topics and guest speakers - see Facebook page for details

Everyone welcome.

If you would like to join please contact using the details above. 

The group meets on the first Thursday of the month October to May with a break during the summer months.

Please note there is also no meeting in January.

If you are unsure if a meeting is taking please contact Jill or visit the Facebook page for more information.

organization.description: Brigg and District gardening club - regular meetings to discuss various gardening topics and listen to guest speakers

name: Brigg Community Hub
description:
Our community hubs

Our community hubs are based throughout North Lincolnshire. They make it easier for residents to access information, advice and support, and take part in activities to improve their health and wellbeing.

The hub spaces are open to everyone. They are a central point in the community with support and activities for all – young and old.

Aim of the hubs

The aim of the hubs is to:

  • improve health and wellbeing and outcomes for local people
  • develop skills and employability for residents, with a clear path to skilled jobs
  • create employment and volunteering opportunities
  • reduce social isolation by connecting residents to activities and services in the community
  • provide information, advice and guidance to local people based on individual need.

The offer in the hubs is built around the five steps to wellbeing. Easy-to-access programmes such as physical activity, social action, volunteering, health and wellbeing, employability and more are available. These activities enable people to maintain their independence, improve their health and wellbeing and develop a range of skills.

Direct help, advice and guidance is provided to meet the needs of residents and enable them to access the support and information they need to live safe, well, prosperous and connected lives.

Hub programmes

Examples of what is available to residents through the hubs programme includes:

  • bespoke IT training sessions to enable residents to take advantage of the social and economic benefits of being online
  • health checks for eligible residents as well as a range of specialist surgeries at certain times throughout the week
  • adult education and family learning sessions
  • general advice and support on council and community services
  • physical activity sessions to enable residents to get more active
  • health sessions around common medical conditions such as cardio-vascular disease and rehabilitation programme for people with chronic joint pain
  • social wellbeing activities that bring the community together such as healthy eating sessions, book clubs and knit and natter sessions.
  • a range of activities for children and young people which support wellbeing, including clubs and school holiday activities.

Facilities within the hub spaces include sport and leisure facilities, public libraries, digital technology, lifelong learning facilities, community kitchens and much more.

The flexible spaces are intended to support a range of community-led activity provided for by a range of organisations across public and voluntary sectors, who can provide additional health and wellbeing support. By working through these integrated approaches, members of the community receive joined up, quality, consistent information and support.

Community Hubs are located across North Lincolnshire within central and accessible locations in:

  • Ashby
  • Barton
  • Brigg
  • Crowle
  • Epworth
  • Riddings
  • Scunthorpe

To find the address of your local hub see the libraries and community hubs page

If you are feeling lonely or isolated, then please feel free to contact your local community hub on the phone numbers below. Or just drop in and say hello. You will always be given a warm welcome.

Contact

  • Barton and Winterton –01724 296808
  • Brigg  – 01724 296776
  • Scunthorpe – 01724 860161
  • Epworth – 01724 296870
  • Crowle –07825 901679

organization.name: North Lincolnshire Community Hubs
organization.description:
North Lincolnshire Council connects residents with their communities through a network of locality-based community hubs enabling independence and wellbeing. 
The Community Hubs support residents by providing a safe environment to access information, activities, skills and services, and by providing the tools to enhance personal knowledge, confidence and a sense of belonging.  
The majority of North Lincolnshire residents live within a 15 minute drive of their local community hub. Hubs are located in each of the following locations Scunthorpe, Brigg, Barton, Crowle, Epworth, Ashby & Riddings.

name: Brigg Community Stroll
description:
Would you like a gentle stroll in friendly company?​​​​​​​

Join our friendly group for a gentle stroll along the banks of the river Ancholme. Come along and experience the fresh air while having a chat and a laugh with new friends. We take the pram and wheelchair friendly route. After the walk join us for a wind down, enjoy some refreshments while carrying on the conversation.

We meet every Friday, in the Angel car park from 10.30am (10.15am if new to the group)  

We look forward to welcoming you.

For more information, please contact the Community Wellbeing Team on - 01724 297214

organization.name: Community Wellbeing
organization.description: The aim of the Community Wellbeing team is to reduce social isolation, empower community groups and reconnect communities

name: Brigg Heritage Centre - Welcome
description:
A warm BHC welcome!

Brigg Heritage Centre, hire facilities and public parking are all fully accessible. Please do not hesitate to contact us should you have any questions regarding your visit.

A 'raft' of adventure... Brigg Heritage Centre is situated in the heart of Brigg, within the beautiful, iconic and historic Angel building (1st floor).

​Our star exhibit, the Bronze Age Raft (known as the 'Brigg Raft' - which dates back to 800BC), was excavated from the River Ancholme, and sets the scene for a fascinating journey, charting the rise of Brigg as an important and influential market place, through to the picturesque town we know today. At the heart of all we do is education, with children crafts, POP-UP exhibitions, talks, creative workshops and events... there is always something new!

We are open to the general public 10am - 2pm on Tuesdays, Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays.

organization.description: Men in sheds Brigg is a charity supporting anyone aged 18+ in the Brigg area, by offering services to encourage social and creative meetings, thus hoping to help ease loneliness and isolation within the community.

name: Brigg Methodist Church
description:
Brigg Methodist Church provides opportunities for worship and fellowship to all.

Our premises are adaptable, with disabled access and available for hire to local groups. We meet at 10.30am every Sunday for a variety of styles of worship followed by coffee and chat. Our services are relayed live via Zoom to those who are housebound. We have a weekly coffee morning from 10am to 12pm every Thursday.

There is a ladies group that meets every other Wednesday afternoon at 2pm. Prayer meetings are held once a month on a Thursday morning. Community groups that meet on our premises include Brigg Singers, Brigg Horticultural Society, MIND, and Christian Bikers Group. A youth club for 11 to 15 year olds has been recently set up as has an Adult youth club. A children's Cheeky Pandas club meets on the second Sunday of each month at 10.30.

name: Brigg Peer Support Group
description:
Carer Peer Support Groups can offer empathetic support that only another Carer can give. They are a great way to meet other Carers, socialise, develop friendships and share information.

Carers meet on the third Thursday of every month from 1pm to 3pm at the Carers' Support Centre and you will be made very welcome.

Talk to us if you feel you cannot attend because of your caring role on 01652 650585 or email info@carerssupportcentre.com

organization.name: Carers' Support Service
organization.description: The Carers’ Support Centre is a charity that has been supporting Carers for nearly 30 years. We are here to work with Carers to ensure they receive the right support and information at the right time, enabling them to continue looking after members of their family, friends and neighbours.

name: Brigg Recreation Ground
description:
Brigg Recreation Ground, Brigg provides top class, fully accessible facilities for the community and local sports clubs.

Brigg Recreation Ground has the following facilities available:

  • Four tennis courts
  • Two mini tennis courts
  • Synthetic hockey pitch. Can be used full or half size
  • Three synthetic, six-a-side football pitches
  • Cricket pitch (summer only)
  • One adult grass football pitch, for 22 players
  • One junior grass football pitch, for 22 players
  • One junior grass football pitch, for 18 players
  • Two mini grass football pitches, for 14 players
  • Two mini grass football pitches, for 10 players

There are four large, heated changing rooms with integrated toilets and modern showers. There is storage with automatic roller shutters included.

There is an accessible changing room with hoist, adjustable sink and shower bed.

The function room has kitchen facilities, underfloor heating and panoramic views of the pitches. The following groups, activities and events can be hosted in our function room. If your activity is not listed here, please contact us as we may be able to help.

  • Meetings
  • Indoor fitness classes
  • Receptions, for example, wedding receptions
  • Local groups and societies, for example, sports teams, community groups, Beavers, Brownies, Cubs, Scouts.

Please email bookings.pods@northlincs.gov.uk or call 01724 291900 to make your booking or submit a booking request using our online form: Hire of sport facilities application form - About this form - NORTHLINCS.GOV.UK (achieveservice.com). Hire prices can be found on the NL Active price list page.​​​​​​​

Brigg Recreation Ground
Wrawby Road
Brigg
North Lincolnshire
DN20 8DT

organization.name: NLActive
organization.description: North Lincolnshire Council manages a number of NLActive centres and sports facilities across North Lincolnshire. Some facilities are located on hub sites so the public can access multiple services at one location. NLActive also runs a community outreach programme and works with local communities to enable them to find a way to help their residents lead a more active lifestyle.

name: Brigg Youth Club
description: Youth Club created to provide a safe space where young people aged between 11 and 14 years can relax, play games, enhancing their wellbeing and developing their social and emotional skills. With a range of structures and unstructured sessions for all abilities.

organization.name: Oikos Brigg
organization.description:
Oikos is a Greek word which literally translates to English as House, but more accurately - Home.  A place where you can be yourself, be fed, cared for and listened to.

Oikos - Brigg is a town centre shop with a difference! A unique not-for-profit charity established so that Christians of all denominations and none can work together to provide love and practical support for local families.

We strive to be a friendly, caring community where everyone is welcome and valued.

Put simply, our vision is to support our local community and as followers of Jesus, grow together, in faith, in hope and in love.

name: Broughton Youth Club
description: Broughton Youth Club provide a wide range of activities for young people aged 9-16years (school years 5-11). Activities include pool, Nintendo Switch, craft, puzzles, sports and many more. The youth centre also provides a chill area for young people to hang out, listen to music and chat. Our trained and experienced youth workers are able to support young people with social and personal developmental skills this has previously included supporting young people with homework.

organization.name: Positive Activities
organization.description: Positive Activities for children and young people aged 8-18 years.

name: Brumby Hall Bowls Club
description:
BRUMBY HALL BOWLS CLUB is a facility for all members of the public and not, as many believe, just for steelworkers.

The club are in five leagues (including a ladies) which cater for bowlers of all abilities. Whether you have played before or are new to bowling there is a team to suit you. If you only want a friendly game with a few mates then the green and clubhouse is open every day from mid morning to dusk for you to enjoy.

Any member of the public is welcome to have a go as we run free taster sessions every Saturday morning starting at 10 am. If you fancy a go all we ask is that you wear flat soled footwear or trainers and everything else is provided.

Our playing season runs from mid April to mid September (weather permitting). 

Societies, company’s or groups can hire the green for a small charge and enjoy a game with friends or colleagues.

If you are bitten by the bug the club run numerous competitions and fun days throughout the summer.

Bowling is also a gentle way to get active and is a low- impact, therapeutic exercise that can improve fitness, coordination and confidence  for everyone, young or old. . It is also fun, social and friendly. If you are looking for something to get you off the couch then why not give it a try.

Brumby Hall Bowls Club is part of a much larger sports facility and the small annual fee entitles you to join other sections (at extra cost) such as an 18 hole par 3 golf course, squash, hockey, angling, cricket, fitness suite, football, running, snooker, table tennis, tennis and other activities such as a chess club, radio club and a photographic club. All of these facilities are in central Scunthorpe behind the Pods Leisure Centre on Ashby Road with ample car parking and near to bus routes. 

Further information is available for bowling at email redpepper2@yahoo.com or telephone 07922 552515.

Information for all the other activities is available on 01724 402053.

organization.name: Brumby Hall Bowls Club
organization.description:
Our Brumby Hall Bowls Club is located at the Brumby hall behind the Pods.

If you have interest in joining a friendly bowls club but you are not sure about becoming a member yet, then please get in touch.

name: Burton Short Mat Bowls Club
description:
Burton Short Mat Bowls Club - we have 20 members. We play on Thursday afternoon and Sunday afternoon 2-4pm in Burton Stather Village Hall.

Everyone welcome. 

If you would like to join, please email Annie Mumby on the details above.

organization.name: Burton Short Mat Bowls Club
organization.description:
The Short Mat Bowls Club meet at Burton upon Stather Village Hall. 
Players of all standards are welcome (even if you have never picked up a bowl before).

League matches are held as well as the practice sessions and all you need is a pair of flat soled shoes. A set of lawn bowls can be borrowed until you are ready to purchase your own.

name: Business Debtline
description:
Business Debtline is a registered charity. We are a free debt advice service for the self-employed and small businesses in England, Wales and Scotland. We have helped thousands of people deal with their debts.

Our team of expert debt advisers care about improving your situation and will help you to take control of your debts. You can call or use webchat to contact us as many times as you need to. If you haven’t contacted us before and want to know what the best way to deal with your debts is, see our Getting ready for advice fact sheet first.

Please call on the number above or visit the website to speak to an advisor via their web chat service available Monday to Friday 9am-5pm.

organization.name: The Money Advice Trust
organization.description: The Money Advice Trust helps people across the UK to tackle their debts and manage their money with confidence.

name: Butterfly Line
description:
The Butterfly Line is a telephone service available to North Lincolnshire palliative and end of life patients, their families and carers.

Specialist nurses from Lindsey Lodge Hospice are available over the telephone 24 hours a day and are able to give timely palliative and end of life care advice. 

01724 454392

organization.name: Lindsey Lodge Hospice and Healthcare
organization.description:
Lindsey Lodge Hospice provides care for adults with life limiting illnesses and aims to provide specialist palliative care for day and inpatients to the highest standard, consisting of symptom management, emotional support and end of life care.

We provide a wide range of services including symptom management, physiotherapy and a lymphoedema service, as well as complimentary therapy, nursing and practical care, emergency care, end of life care along with bereavement and family support services.

name: Cafe Fellowship
description: On the second and fourth Tuesday of every month, members of the public are welcome to join our friendly group for refreshments and informal conversations around faith and beliefs.

name: Canoe Marathon and Sprint Racing - lessons and training
description:
Learn to paddle racing kayaks or canoes to race in marathon and sprint disciplines! Coaching is by Paddle UK (formally British Canoeing) qualified coaches. All our coaches are DBS checked and have appropriate first aid, safeguarding and rescue qualifications. 

These sessions run all year, weather permitting on Saturday afternoons, and summer only on Tuesday evenings. Cost is £6 per session for your first session of the week, and just £2 for any other sessions in the same week.

We are an Inclusive Club: We promote Equality, Diversity and Inclusion. Our youngest paddlers are from age six to eight years old, if our buoyancy aids fit. There is no upper age limit.

For more information visit our website: www.gscc-online.com or our Facebook page www.facebook.com/FriendsOfGSCC

Our bookings/membership number is 07811 619360. New paddlers must complete a membership application form before their first session on the water, but do not need to join the club until their fourth session.

Cost to join our club is £15 per year for individual membership and £40 per family of four (Two adults and two children or one adult and three children).

Our Membership Application form can be downloaded from https://docs.google.com/document/d/1nx04L0THThnnwSSL8BG-4ITXpGgiY0-2/edit?usp=drive_link&ouid=109734965754123315622&rtpof=true&sd=true

organization.name: Glanford and Scunthorpe Canoe Club
organization.description:
We are a friendly canoeing and kayaking club in North Lincolnshire, based on the River Ancholme at Brigg.

We are an Inclusive Club: We promote Equality, Diversity and Inclusion

From April to September we paddle on the River Ancholme, meeting in our boathouse just behind the Ancholme Lesiure Centre.

From October to March we paddle in the Pool at the Ancholme Lesiure Centre. More information about our river and pool sessions can be found on the sessions page.

We actively promote most canoeing activities such as white water, canoe polo and marathon, sprint and slalom racing. To find out more please visit out disciplines page.

We also cater for the tourer with river trips.

name: Capes Carps Fishery
description:
Fishing from 6am until dusk.

Opening hours - 12hrs and 24 hrs by agreement.

Please ring or message for details.

organization.description:
kirtoninlindsey.com is a community website featuring information on all facilities, community groups, fitness classes and useful links in the area.

Kirton in Lindsey is a picturesque town in Lincolnshire and is situated approximately an hour’s drive from the cities of Leeds and Sheffield, and only 30 minutes from Lincoln.

name: Care Act Advocacy
description:
What is Care Act Advocacy?

The Care Act says that local councils must involve people in decisions about their care and support needs.  If it would be difficult for someone to be involved without support the council must make sure they get the help they need. If the person doesn’t have someone who can help them they have the right to have an independent Care Act advocate.


Who can be supported by a Care Act advocate?

Care Act advocates can support:

  • Adults who need care and support
  • Carers
  • Children who are moving to adult care services

If the council is making decisions about your care and support they must consider whether you would have ‘substantial difficulty’ being involved. Substantial difficulty would be if you have problems with one or more of these:

  • Understanding information about the decisions
  • Remembering information
  • Using the information to be involved in the decisions
  • Being able to tell people your views, wishes and feelings

The council then needs to consider whether you have an ‘appropriate individual’ to support you. This is someone who the council agree will be available and able to support you. It can be someone in your family or a friend but won’t be someone you don’t want to support you. It can’t be someone who is paid to look after you.

If the council decide that you would have substantial difficulty being involved and do not have an appropriate individual to support you, then you have the right to a Care Act advocate.


How can a Care Act advocate help me?

An advocate will support you to be involved as much as possible in decisions about your care. Your advocates can help you when the council is:

  • Making a needs assessment
  • Making a carer’s assessment
  • Making or reviewing a care and support plan
  • Having a safeguarding enquiry (to check if you might be being abused) or arranging for a Safeguarding Adults Review

Your advocate will work with you to help you understand what is happening and to give your views; they can speak for you if you can’t. Your advocate can help you to think about your choices and what is best for you. If you want to challenge the council’s decision your advocate can help you do this too.


How do I get support from a Care Act advocate?

Referrals are made through the local council. Please contact us if you need more information.

organization.name: POhWER
organization.description:
We help people who, because of disability, illness, social exclusion and other challenges, find it difficult to express their views or get the support they need. 

Our mission is to deliver high quality advocacy, information and advice services empowering people to have a voice and to make a real difference to their lives.

We are a charity and the advocacy, information and advice services we provide are free, independent and confidential.

As an independent organisation we are separate from the government, local councils and the NHS and we always put the wishes and needs of the people we work with first.

name: Care Finding Service
description:
Meet Lottie - your trusted (and free) guide to understanding, finding, and funding care.

Proudly rated the UK’s most popular care-finding service with a 4.9* Trustpilot score, Lottie’s directory allows families to easily compare local services and find their perfect care solution within their budgets.

Lottie offers families full visibility of the care market, including every registered care home and home care service in North Lincolnshire. Unlike other directory services, Lottie’s vetted listings include detailed information about the care service’s availability and the type of care provided, as well as extensive photography, videos, and virtual tours.

You can use Lottie to search and compare care homes in North Lincolnshire by type of care, weekly cost, CQC rating, facilities, and so much more. 

Whether you’re looking for a dementia care home in North Lincolnshire or a home care provider in North Lincolnshire offering nursing care services, Lottie is on hand to empower you to make a quick and an informed decision. You can even look for access to a landscaped garden, or the option to move into a retirement home with your beloved pet.

With a strong focus on quality and transparency, Lottie puts care seekers and their loved ones at the heart of everything it does to ensure all families feel supported and well-equipped throughout their care search process.
