name: Experts by Experience
description:
Experts by Experience

Information about the Experts by Experience in North Lincolnshire. How you can get involved to make a difference and help to shape services across North Lincolnshire.

Have your say and make a difference

The Experts by Experience is a way for people to get involved, have their say and make a difference.

The group are volunteers who have a wide range of experience of different services across  Adult Social Care, and share their experiences and hands on knowledge from using the services.  This lived experience helps North Lincolnshire Council to shape services.

The Experts by Experience work on:

  • mystery shopping
  • interviews
  • working with other services
  • regular updates with the Safeguarding team
  • the Pledge
  • other specific projects

The group meet monthly to look at and share information.  There are ‘lite bite’ training sessions available and the group also discuss and plan new projects. 

Dependant on the project, relevant officers are invited to attend meetings to talk about their service and how we can work together, using the benefit of peoples lived experience to see how things can be changed and shaped and influence future developments.

If you think you might be interested in joining us and have some lived experience of Adult Social Care please get in touch.

A ‘Nothing About You Without You’ video has been developed through the Experts by Experience group and provides an overview of the importance of people having their say and how they can get involved.

Take a look at the video:

Further information

What sort of work can I get involved in?

How can I get involved?

Contact

expert.experience@northlincs.gov.uk

Tel: 01724 296394

Terms of reference

name: Ezio
description:
Formed in 1990 Ezio are singer/songwriter Ezio Lunedei and guitarist and best friend Booga (Mark Fowell). Since forming they’ve released many studio and live albums from the critically acclaimed Black Boots on Latin Feet (Arista/Ariola produced by the late Rupert Hine) Diesel Vanilla (MCA Universal produced Peter Van Hooke and Rod Argent) to the most recent release Daylight Moon. In this time Ezio has toured and performed around the globe gaining a reputation for dynamic and exciting performances delivered with energy, humour and emotional beauty. Because of this the duo has sustained a large and loyal international long-term following that was built mainly through word of mouth.

Please visit the website to book.

organization.description: NL Family hubs - supporting families across North Lincolnshire

name: Family Sessions
description:
Sometimes you have too much to fit in a day, a week or a month. Work, family, fitness. What comes first & what gets left behind?

If you want to join the fun & fitness together then 1:1 is for you. It’s so important to not just say you think something like your health is important, it’s good to SHOW your kids you think it is. And not to just disappear from family time to visit the gym. Why not encourage them from an early age to get active & get fit. Let us give you a program you can ‘play’ with your kids. 1:1 Family coaching is for you if you want to focus on YOUR goals, & and work on your health, fitness and wellbeing, but it also builds your family into a healthy unit.

Prices are from £30 per 45 minutes, To make those big changes in life, it is better to meet up on a regular basis. Prices will depend on the number of family members being trained.

organization.name: New Beginnings
organization.description:
New Beginnings Personal Training and Wellness Facility offer the highest quality services and treatments for mind, body and wellness.


Our services are provided by highly qualified personal trainers who are experts in their field and hand selected by the New Beginning's owner and founder, Stacey Greenfield. 


Feeling good is a complex issue. Health is at the heart of it, but psychology has a role to play as well, and we need to have that feeling of looking good.


New Beginnings brings together a range of services for mind, body and wellness to help our clients be fit and well inside and out. The best way to great health is to look after the whole body, not just the physical aspects but also the mental issues as well; as the saying goes "Healthy Body, Healthy Mind".


Looking after your health as a whole package is so important, yet it is something that far too many people sadly neglect.  Our range of services has been put together in such a way that many of them complement each other.


Our fully equipped personal training studio allows clients to work out in comfort and privacy. In addition this allows clients to also benefit from the expert advice of our personal trainers either with one-to-one support based on their individual goals or small group classes such as yoga.


Our New Beginnings founder is also qualified in nutrition and is available to put together the best possible programme to assist with weight loss, fitness issues and helping to create a health body. For those clients who have issues with food, we can assist with this. Helping you to create a more positive and healthier person both on the outside and as well as on the inside can give you the real boost of confidence that can be invaluable in both a professional and personal capacity. 

From counselling to life coaching, our highly professional team can help you to overcome whatever it is that is preventing you from achieving your goals.

name: FamilyLine
description:
Families come in all shapes and sizes. No matter how they are constructed, Family Action is committed to supporting them to realise their potential.

All families encounter difficult and challenging times and many will find ways to deal with their problems, getting the support they need from friends and relatives.

There are times, however, when problems can seem too overwhelming to manage.

Family Action works to tackle some of the most complex and difficult issues facing families today – including financial hardship, mental health problems, social isolation, learning disabilities, domestic abuse, or substance misuse and alcohol problems.

These issues can have a huge impact on the stability of family life, and will have a significant impact on the health, wellbeing and development of all family members.

Family Action believes that families facing these difficulties should have the support they need to become stronger, happier and healthier. With the right kind of support, families can overcome their difficulties and find hope for a brighter future.

Supporting adult family members via telephone, text, email and web chat

We’re here to provide a listening ear, answer particular parenting questions or help with guidance around more complex issues. All support takes place via telephone, text message or email and is free.

  •  0808 802 6666
  •  Text: 07537 404 282
  •  familyline@family-action.org.uk
  •  Mon-Fri, 9am to 9pm

Contacting us out of hours

Do you need FamilyLine but it’s out of our operation hours? You can either call back in our opening hours, leave a message on our voice mail for a call back in our operation hours or if you’re in crisis you can contact our crisis line to get in touch with a trained professional.
Text FAMILYACTION to 85258

Our crisis messenger text service provides free, 24/7 crisis support across the UK. We know that getting the correct support at the correct time is so beneficial which is why we’ve introduced our crisis line.

organization.name: Family Action
organization.description:
Family Action transforms lives by providing practical, emotional and financial support to those who are experiencing poverty, disadvantage and social isolation across the country.

We have been building stronger families since 1869, and today work with over 60,000 families through our 200 community-based services. Thousands more are supported with financial assistance through education and welfare grants programmes.

Our innovative services reach out to those in need, we strengthen families and communities, build skills and resilience and improve the life chances of children and adults.

name: Fatigue & Breathlessness
description:
This service is for people who are diagnosed with cancer or a progressive life limiting disease such as Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), heart failure or multiple sclerosis,that affects their energy levels and breathing. Being fatigued, and particularly breathless, can be a very worrying or frightening experience, both for you and for the people around you at the time. It may affect how well you are able to do things such as climbing stairs, bathing, walking or going out. The aim of the FAB service is to help you and your family or carer cope with your symptoms.

You can self-refer into the FAB service or a healthcare professional such as your GP or complex care matron can complete a referral for you. Your first contact with our service will be via a member of the administrator team. The administrator will arrange for you to attend for a face-to-face assessment or if you would prefer, a telephone assessment with the clinical specialist physiotherapist or advanced care practitioner occupational therapist. Following your initial assessment, you will be offered further intervention via this service on a one to one basis or you will be allocated a place on our Breathe Easy Enablement Programme (BEEP). During your initial assessment, the physiotherapist or occupational therapist will explore your symptoms and how they affect your life. They will also look at how you breathe and explore what happens when you feel fatigued/breathless and what activities make you fatigued/breathless. You will be given the opportunity to ask questions and to gain a greater understanding about how best to manage your condition. You will be encouraged to set goals to help you manage functional and social activities and you will begin to learn about different strategies to help you manage your fatigue and breathlessness.

The one to one sessions are designed to provide specific focus for you depending on your most prominent symptom and you will begin working with the most appropriate healthcare professional to meet your needs. In the first instance, if fatigue is your main difficulty, you will likely be allocated for input with our occupational therapist - if breathlessness is your main difficulty, you will likely be allocated for input with our physiotherapist. Areas that we will cover during one to one sessions include: Coping with fatigue We will explore techniques to help you cope with your fatigue. We will, if appropriate, advise you about the following: • Keeping a fatigue/activity diary • Ergonomic assessments • Pacing, planning and prioritisation of activities • Cognition • Mood • Sleep hygiene • Relaxation and mindfulness techniques • Advice on managing meaningful occupations such as washing, dressing, working and gardening • Goal setting • Vocational rehabilitation (staying in and/or returning to work) Managing Breathlessness • Breathing control techniques • Positions to help alleviate breathlessness • Fan therapy • How to conserve energy during everyday activities • How to pace activities (such as stairs) • How to manage anxiety/panic attacks • Relaxation techniques • Chest clearance techniques (if required) • Exercises We will also endeavour to help alleviate your fears in relation to your breathlessness. Attending the clinic will also enable us and assist you to recognise symptoms that require medical intervention so that you can receive treatment sooner rather than later.

The group programme runs for a period of 8 weeks and the content is designed to support both you and your main carer, be that a relative or friend. The group delivers a programme of education and support alongside advice and practice of exercises and movement that aim to enhance your quality of life. The education sessions are designed for both you and your carer. You will then participate in our tailored exercise programme, whilst your carer has the opportunity to access an advice and support session with our registered counsellor. The BEEP programme includes advice and support which covers: • Breathlessness management • Energy conservation and fatigue • Planning for the future • Anxiety and low mood • Managing your disease and recognising red flags • Sleep hygiene • Relaxation and mindfulness Depending on whether you attend for one to one intervention or intervention as group, you will be expected to put into practice what you have learned and progress will be reviewed during follow up conversations. Emotional and other support We appreciate that fatigue and breathlessness can be a frustrating and difficult symptom to live with and that it can affect you psychologically as well as physically. Your care team aims to support you through your treatment when you are referred into the fatigue and breathlessness service however other services such as complementary therapy and counselling may be recommended to offer support in conjunction with your fatigue and breathlessness management plans to help implement strategies in the longer term. These services can be accessed via your care team if required. How will I get there? The service requires you to make your own way to your appointments. If you have transport problems, the voluntary car service may be able to help (mileage rates apply) or alternatively, a remote assessment/support can be provided. How long is my treatment likely to last? One to one sessions vary from 1 – 1 ½ hours depending on your needs. When attending the group programme (BEEP), the session will last approximately 2 hours however will be a mixture of education and exercise. Once you have completed your sessions, you will be discharged back to the care of your GP. However should you require support in the future, you will be able to contact the FAB service directly for any help or support after this time if required. Sources of further information Cancellations Due to the large number of patients requiring treatment and the limited availability of clinic appointments we are required to have a strict cancellation policy.

If you cancel or do not attend three appointments or more, we may discharge you from the service and notification of this will be sent to your GP. Any further treatment will require a new referral from an appropriate healthcare practitioner. In the event of extenuating circumstances this may be reviewed. Please give as much notice as possible when cancelling appointments so that your appointment slot can be offered to someone else

We provide a wide range of services including symptom management, physiotherapy and a lymphoedema service, as well as complimentary therapy, nursing and practical care, emergency care, end of life care along with bereavement and family support services.

name: First Steps Forward
description:
First Steps Forward (FSF) is an exciting new project being delivered in partnership with Community Vision, Westcliffe Community Works, and Crosby Community Association, which is being built around strengthening our deprived communities, with particular emphasis on the experiences of young children up to the age of five, and their wider families. The aim of the project is to help tackle the broad inequalities that some families face, which significantly impact on the future life chances of children and perpetuate an intergenerational cycle of deprivation.

Currently the service is only operational within Scunthorpe communities, because this is where the highest level of inequalities sits. As a community-based approach, it is important that we strengthen the support by working with other community-based services and that is why we are working in partnership with VANL, NL MIND, Westcliffe Community Works, and Crosby Community Association, who are operating in the heart of community and therefore best placed to engage and enable wider community groups and organisations to welcome and support families to benefit. The benefits of this approach for families will be increased confidence, skills, and aspirations, creating a culture of acceptance and inclusion.

The support will address the risks and barriers faced by families and deliver a bespoke service aimed at meeting the whole needs of the family in achieving a positive, successful, and healthy life by offering the following:

​Parenting Support

  • Coaching, mentoring, and working towards personal goals and aspirations.

  • Supporting to improve relationships with family, friends, and community.

  • Navigation and support to understand and improve relationships with other agencies, i.e. schools, health, and social workers etc

  • Practical help to ensure the safety of adults and children.

  • Mental Health, counselling and wellbeing support offered by NL MIND.

The service is now ‘live’ and offering bespoke support to families, which will be tailored to the needs identified by parents themselves and designed to specifically address their needs, goals, and aspirations. It will happen in the place the family feels most comfortable in, including their own home. Families will be offered 1 to 1 support provided by family Support Coordinators staff and volunteers.

​Referral for Support 

If you are a parent of a child under five living in Scunthorpe and feel like you need support to deal with issues affecting the wellbeing of your family, please contact us to hear how we can help. Our support in confidential and non-judgemental and you choose whether to accept help or not.

Call Lynne (based at Community Vision) on 01724 845155 option 7, Sophie (based at Crosby Community Association) on 07789 908635, Adelle (based at Westcliff Community Centre) on 07900 875031, Anna (based at MIND) 07762 483398.

Referrers can access the referral form here

organization.name: North Lincolnshire Mind
organization.description:
We are here to help you in your recovery journey and whenever you need mental health support. We believe that everyone should have access to good mental health support whenever they need it.

Here at North Lincolnshire Mind, we have created a safe and supportive environment where we provide a variety of services from 1 to 1 Confidential Listening service to recovery-focused groups and social support sessions.

name: Fitness 4 Fun
description:
Peer led exercise group, sessions are varied but involve cardio and weighted exercise for all levels of ability. A fun vibe with friendly people!

Any ability and no booking, just turn up.

See website link for more details

name: Fitness Pilates and Yoga sculpt
description:
​Monday 6pm

A mixed ability mat Pilates and stretch session with weights. Held at Frodingham Community Centre, Scunthorpe. £6 for a taster class. £8 Pay as Go, £7 with our membership silver or gold packages. Contact us for more details.

We also offer a range of class sessions and private 1 to 1 sessions. We love everything Pilates, Yoga, Yogalates. Beginner classes and mixed ability sessions. We offer On demand videos, a range of pay as you go, memberships and monthly subscriptions payment options.

name: Fitness Sessions
description:
Fitness Sessions

Mon 6.15pm - One hour fitness session using weights, full body workout

Tues 6pm - One hour box-fit session - wearing boxing gloves, using freestanding and hung bags

Wed 10.30am - Meet and greet, 45 minute seated exercise class, then tea and biscuits afterwards

Wed 6pm - One hour fitness session using weights, full body workout

Thurs 9am - One hour fitness session using weights, full body workout

organization.name: Jaime's Fit Club
organization.description: Jaime's Fit Club offering sports massage, personal training, Adult Fit Club 16+, rebounding and indoor fitness sessions.

name: Food Bank
description: Food Bank

organization.name: Scunthorpe Salvation Army
organization.description:
The Salvation Army is a worldwide Christian church and registered charity, which has been fighting against social inequality and transforming lives for over 150 years.
The Salvation Army expresses its faith through charitable action by working at the heart of communities across the UK and Ireland. We have 650 churches and community centres where we offer friendship, practical help and support to some of the most disadvantaged people in our communities.

Motivated by our Christian faith we offer practical support and services to all who need them, regardless of ethnicity, religion, gender or sexual orientation. Our work includes:

Homelessness
Modern slavery
Poverty
Addiction
Campaigning and social policy
Older people
Community - debt advice, unemployment, isolation
Your support allows us to respond to the people who need us most. Across the UK and Ireland, we:

Provide over 3,000 places every night in 82 lifehouses
Supported over 13,000 people through our Employment service
Supported over 11,000 victims referred to our modern slavery services
The United Kingdom and Ireland is part of the wider international Salvation Army, which changes lives in 131 countries around the world.

name: Food Pantry
description: A donation of £4 for a basket full of a variety of foods, including fresh, frozen and ambient. Anybody is welcome to come and shop with us.

organization.name: Oikos Brigg
organization.description:
Oikos is a Greek word which literally translates to English as House, but more accurately - Home.  A place where you can be yourself, be fed, cared for and listened to.

Oikos - Brigg is a town centre shop with a difference! A unique not-for-profit charity established so that Christians of all denominations and none can work together to provide love and practical support for local families.

We strive to be a friendly, caring community where everyone is welcome and valued.

Put simply, our vision is to support our local community and as followers of Jesus, grow together, in faith, in hope and in love.

name: Foodbank project
description:
​​​​​​​​​​​​Citizens Advice North Lincolnshire are working in partnership with Scunthorpe Foodbank to offer a ‘more than food approach’. Individuals who are eligible to receive a parcel from the Foodbank will be given the opportunity to receive advice and support from a Citizens Advice generalist adviser. 


Citizens Advice is a referral partner of Scunthorpe Foodbank. Call our office information line 01724 870941 between 10am and 4pm on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays.

organization.name: Citizens Advice North Lincolnshire
organization.description:
We give people the knowledge and confidence they need to find their way forward - whoever they are, and whatever their problem.

Our national charity and network of local charities offer confidential advice online, over the phone, and in person, for free.

name: Football for Down Syndrome players
description: Football Training Sessions

organization.name: Bottesford Town Football Club
organization.description: Bottesford Town Football Club - local ran football team with additional teams and leagues supporting North Lincolnshire residents to get active and enjoy football.

name: Foresight
description: At Foresight, we are a dedicated organisation committed to meeting the needs and requirements of disabled individuals, their families, and carers in North and North East Lincolnshire. We not only host daily activities and opportunities for the disabled community but we also offer support with applying for housing grants and fuel vouchers. Furthermore, we have several residential buildings with efficient support from our housing team. The opportunity to volunteer at our Foresight building, or any of our Hubs (Including Scartho Library) is there for all!

organization.name: Foresight North East Lincolnshire
organization.description: At Foresight, we are a dedicated organisation committed to meeting the needs and requirements of disabled individuals, their families, and carers in North and North East Lincolnshire. Our mission is to provide the way forward for the disabled community, empowering individuals to a new beginning, a brighter future, and a full and enjoyable life.

name: Fostering
description:
North Lincolnshire Council provides different types of foster care to meet the different needs of our children and young people. How long you care for a foster child depends on the type of foster care you are approved for.

North Lincolnshire Council’s fostering services team was inspected and judged as Outstanding by Ofsted. 

Our award-winning film, ‘Any Of Us’, shows that any one of us has the potential to foster, if you have a big heart to care.

The film challenges misconceptions about fostering and is the largest public sector fostering film collaboration yet, with over 80 participants from local authorities around the UK.

Could you join our fostering family and be that someone who needs to be there? You can watch our film on the North Lincolnshire Council's fostering webpage.

If you are interested in fostering or want to find out more, please contact our team on fostering@northlincs.gov.uk, call 01724 297000 or attend one of our fostering information events.

name: Fostering Friendly Scheme
description:
Our Fostering Friendly Scheme encourages employers, businesses and organisations to support and recognise the roles of their employees who foster and helps to support the wider community by showing a strong social responsibility to children in care.

Members of the scheme can support in a variety of ways, bespoke to their organisation, including raising awareness in the community, offering discounts for foster carers, providing work experience, or agreeing to put in place a fostering friendly HR policy for all foster carers in their employment.

Being a member of the scheme and what you can offer will be bespoke to your organisation and the team will discuss different options with you.

Current members include John Leggott College, Know Film, Humberside Police, Kimberley Performing Arts Centre, Ongo, Jerry Green Dog Rescue, Scunthorpe United F.C. and many more.

Get in touch today and see how your business or organisation could get involved, champion fostering and raise awareness around the community.

name: Frankish Psychological Services
description:
Counselling/Therapy and Assessment services 

A safe, confidential and accessible service provided by highly experienced therapists, offering a range of approaches and therapy to suit you.

Appointments are required for treatment.  Please telephone to find out more information.

name: FraudWatch
description:
Fraud comes in many different forms, and absolutely anyone can become a victim.

Fraudsters aim to trick individuals into giving away cash, bank details or other personal information; this is done by them contacting thousands of random people.

As part of the FraudWatch project, we would like to encourage charity staff, as well as the general public to take 5 and think ‘could this be a scam?’.

We provide support to the public to report incidents of fraud and cybercrime. 

Please visit the website or contact for more information.

organization.description: Community VISION is a merger of ERVAS and VANL - infrastructure bodies supporting VCSE in ER and NL

Please follow the link to find up to date information about free school meals and school clothing grants in North Lincolnshire.

School food and free school meals - North Lincolnshire Council (northlincs.gov.uk)

organization.description: Find out if your child is eligible for free school meals and apply online. Learn about our healthy menus and how we cater for special dietary requirements.

Come along for a chat and maybe have a go at something new (Arts and Crafts are optional and not a must take part)

Free Tea and Coffee

organization.name: The Arc
organization.description:
We are a friendly well-being hub based in the heart of the Westcliff community and we’re part of Ongo, which means all profit we make is put back into the local community. 

Call into our cafe for a cuppa, find out about events and activities, rent a room, catch up with old friends, or meet new ones. We also have free wifi, a Post Office and loads more to get involved in.

There’s a whole range of support and training available here at The Arc. From our Employment Support Coaches and Housing Officers, to agencies we work with like Humberside Police, North Lindsey College and North Lincolnshire Council. So if you need training or support, come and speak to us.

name: Fresh Food
description: Come and fill a basket with food for just £2

organization.name: Crosby Together
organization.description:
Our vision:
To be the place in the centre of our community that provide space and inspires, equips and enables Crosby towards diversity, sustainability and growth.
Our Mission:
To provide facilities for hire by community members and partner organisations. We use  resource gathered to invest in training and serving our community. We will do this through providing projects and opportunities accessible to all.
Our values:
To enable a community where everyone is valued and is able to add value.

name: Friday Club (Men's Group)
description:
Men's mental health support group

Chat and a cuppa, trips, activities and support.

We look forward to meeting you.

organization.name: Westcliff Community Works
organization.description:
Westcliff Drop-In Centre was established in 1987 and became a registered charity in 1997.  The main focus of the Centre was to work as an independent, community project responding to the needs of the residents of the Westcliff housing estate and surrounding areas.  In 2011 the Drop-In incorporated as a company limited by guarantee. The Board comprises of 8 local residents and 2 associate members.

In May 2018 we moved from our centre, which was earmarked for demolition, into a new community building and changed our name to Westcliff Community Works.

Westcliff Community Works (WCW) is a community anchor organisation “our vision” is for a thriving, united, joyful community filled with inspiration; where all residents have the opportunities and confidence to prosper and lead happy and healthy lives.

name: Friends of Fostering
description:
Join the fostering community in North Lincolnshire by signing up to receive a monthly newsletter of all things fostering.

Find out about:

 - fostering in your area

 - the different types of fostering including short breaks and the supported lodgings scheme

 - the fostering friendly scheme

 - events where you can meet the fostering team including their regular online information evenings

 - updates on fostering friendly members and opportunities for our children in foster care

 - myth busting

Plus so much more straight to your inbox!

name: Fun & Flex
description:
If you are looking for a fun, enjoyable and gentle exercise class then this maybe the class for you. 

Our 60 minute modified strength and balance exercises are designed to help improve posture, strengthen muscles, boost mood and energy levels whilst helping to regain fitness at your own pace.  Fun and Flex is just what is needed for those of you who want to improve your flexibility and balance and improve your mental wellbeing, helping you to relax and de-stress.

Fun and Flex runs weekly on a Friday morning 11:30am - 12:30pm at South Ferriby Village Hall, High Street, South Ferriby, DN18 6HS

organization.name: Community Wellbeing
organization.description: The aim of the Community Wellbeing team is to reduce social isolation, empower community groups and reconnect communities

name: Funding help and support
description:
Community VISION can help support with all your funding needs

Our Advisors will help your community group and charity to –
  • Be fit for funding
  • Write a Funding Plan
  • Understand which funders to apply to and what for
  • Understand why funding applications fail
We are able to offer –
  • Training and workshops
  • One to one sessions
  • Guides for local funders
  • Factsheets and Guides
  • Support with partnerships
  • Advice on your draft applications
  • Bid writing service – ask for information

See more Funding information on our website.... funding.communityvision.org.uk

name: Gaelforce
description:
Gaelforce – winners of the 2023 introducing stage at the Great British folk festival – are a Celtic folk rock band with fiddle & Highland bagpipes who play Scots & Irish tunes and traditional folk songs.

Just seen Gaelforce at Butlin’s. Awesome. Zoe-Anne Wadey

Great set today at Centre Stage Butlins. I am not really into folk but you converted me just a bit. Karen Woodcock

Best band of the weekend – Chris Petz

“CONGRATULATIONS to GAELFORCE, a very deserving winning act on the INTRODUCING STAGE at the GREAT BRITISH FOLK FESTIVAL 2023, going on to play main stage to a capacity, thoroughly entertained audience the following day” – Stephen, Solid Entertainments Festival Director.

For more information and booking details visit the website.

name: GamCare Yorkshire & Humber
description:
GamCare, in partnership with NECA, provide a full range of free, flexible services to support anyone affected by gambling harm across Yorkshire and Humber.


We offer a range of support which can be provided face-to-face, online or over the phone. We can support gamblers as well as those who are affected by the gambling behaviour of a family member or friend. All of our services are free of charge and confidential.

Please visit the website for more information and details of further support.
pc_attendingAccess_additionalInfo: Appointments in person, over the phone or online. Access our service by self referral or, professional referral via the referral form on our website.

description: Table Top games for all abilities, free tea and coffee :)
pc_attendingAccess_additionalInfo: Free parking, Café, Post Office

organization.name: The Arc
organization.description:
We are a friendly well-being hub based in the heart of the Westcliff community and we’re part of Ongo, which means all profit we make is put back into the local community. 

Call into our cafe for a cuppa, find out about events and activities, rent a room, catch up with old friends, or meet new ones. We also have free wifi, a Post Office and loads more to get involved in.

name: Gardening Group - Allotment
description:
Are you keen to get out in the fresh air and would like to meet new people? Do you have an interest in gardening and growing your own vegetables?

We have an amazing space at Wheatfield allotment, Bottesford Lane, Scunthorpe, where we have been working to prepare, plant and grow vegetable produce.

When ready, this produce is then shared with our allotment community group, food banks and our very own healthy lifestyle team, who support people to produce healthy meals.

The allotment space also offers wide paths and raised beds with handrails to allow access for wheelchair users. There are parking spaces available too.

This is a friendly, welcoming group which not only offers the physical side of things but also the social side, which contributes to our mental health and wellbeing.

Would you like to be part of our community group sharing knowledge, the love of gardening and growing of your own produce? Why not join us at this free to attend group on Thursday's 10am-12.30pm. Booking required.

If interested, please contact The Community Wellbeing Team on 01724 297214, Pauline on 07717 587651 or Carol on 07825 858180 for more information.

organization.description: Bringing you the best of UK and Trans-Atlantic folk and roots music. Browse or search our events below to find out more about what’s happening at Town Hall Live. For more information on the artists please click their name. To reserve tickets call Brian Chudley: 01652 649230 or you can purchase tickets through this link https://www.wegottickets.com/kirtontownhall

name: General hiring of the hall for functions
description: The hall can be hired for private parties and other functions. Prices are £15 for the first hour, then £10 per hour for subsequent hours. Discounts will be applicable for residents of Burringham and may be granted for other functions.

organization.name: Burringham Village Hall
organization.description: Venue for range of events including bingo, yoga classes, fun days, parent and toddler group, and coffee mornings.

name: Generic Non-statutory Advocacy
description:
This service is for residents of North Lincolnshire or those registered with a GP in the area who fall outside the remit for statutory advocacy services.

Our advocates can support you to:

• know what options are available to you so you can make decisions about your care and support
• have your views heard and considered when decisions are being made about you
• know your rights and ensure they are upheld
• make a complaint about your social care provision or resolve a dispute about a health, care or support service you are using.

Our services are free, independent and confidential.

You can refer yourself for this type of advocacy or ask a carer or health and social care professional to make a referral on your behalf.

organization.name: POhWER
organization.description:
We help people who, because of disability, illness, social exclusion and other challenges, find it difficult to express their views or get the support they need. 

Our mission is to deliver high quality advocacy, information and advice services empowering people to have a voice and to make a real difference to their lives.

We are a charity and the advocacy, information and advice services we provide are free, independent and confidential.

As an independent organisation we are separate from the government, local councils and the NHS and we always put the wishes and needs of the people we work with first.

name: Get Crafty
description: The 'Get Crafty' group is a weekly arts and crafts session for adults with a disability. This friendly group meet-up is free with no experience needed and no booking required. Tea and coffee is provided for free.

organization.name: 20-21 Visual Arts Centre
organization.description:
About 20-21
Welcome to 20-21 Visual Arts Centre
The entrance to 20-21 Visual Arts Centre
20-21 Visual Arts Centre is housed in the former St. John’s Church building in Church Square, Scunthorpe. Since the gallery’s doors first opened in 2001 we have developed a reputation for offering a varied and exciting exhibition programme of contemporary art, craft and design.  We show around 20 exhibitions per year, across six exhibition spaces, and aim to be as ambitious and creatively diverse.  As well as bringing arts and culture to the local community, we aim to exhibit art by groups that are traditionally under represented in mainstream galleries.

Encompassing a wide range of media, subjects and artistic approaches, we present a mixture of in-house curated exhibitions, touring shows and exhibitions developed in partnership with fellow creative organisations.  We also produce and deliver our own touring exhibitions to other galleries nationally, and offer an extensive education programme for all ages and abilities.

We’re an Arts Council England [National Portfolio Organisation (NPO] which means funding thanks to tax payers and National Lottery players plays a huge part in supporting our work.

name: Girls Football 8+
description: Girls "Wildcats" training sessions and Team Building

organization.name: Bottesford Town Football Club
organization.description: Bottesford Town Football Club - local ran football team with additional teams and leagues supporting North Lincolnshire residents to get active and enjoy football.

name: Grief Cafe
description:
Support for coping with loss

Better understand the grief process

Meet other people experiencing loss 

Talk about your loss or just listen to others 

Every first Wednesday of the month 5.30pm-6.30pm at Oasis Community Space.

organization.name: Oatridge Coaching
organization.description: Oatridge Coaching provides 1-2-1 non-directive coaching to anyone about anything to help them to move forward, grow and develop themselves.  They host Harbour in various locations across North Lincolnshire which is a pop-up space for Co-working, Connecting and Coaching which at present is free to the user as it is fully funded by the UK Government.

name: Group Coaching in Running Fitness
description:
I have a seven week course in Scunthorpe for people that want to learning running techniques and understanding biomechanics to improve your running and getting fitter for longer. Very friendly group learning together with active sessions.

The course has been developed for all abilities, if you can run a 5km to endurance running and beyond the main aim is to maximise your running abilities to stay running and fitter for longer. There will be consultations and analysis of your running and an action plan which will improve your running technique, stamina, endurance, speed, and personal goals for 6 to 12 months. We will be looking at running drills, strengthening/conditioning, balance and coordination during the course so please wear gym clothes.

Each group will have limited numbers so we can concentrate on your journey but still enjoy training with other people. 

Places available for my next coaching courses. Please check back regularly for the next course dates. During winter all sessions will be held at Brumby Hall in Scunthorpe. During the Spring and Summer the sessions will be held outside in Central Park Scunthorpe near to the Nutshell Cafe of Kingsway, Scunthorpe. 

£45 per course. Please email coachingwithjb@gmail.com for the online form.

Please contact for dates of future courses.

organization.name: Coaching in Running Fitness with JB in North Lincolnshire
organization.description: Progressive running group in Scunthorpe

name: Gruoch
description:
Gruoch is a feminist, myth-centred examination of the bereaved and abused girl who became Lady Macbeth as an act of revenge for the death of her father. She did indeed manipulate Macbeth to kill Duncan, but not through vaulting ambition… this “icon of evil” may be the power behind the throne, but as the only woman left alive, her power is used to avenge.

A new solo performance, written by David Calcutt and performed by award-winning actor Caroline Burns Cooke.

£14/£16 OTD

Tickets can be purchased via the Ropery Hall website, in person, or over the phone on 01652 660380

name: Guitar Club - Living Later Life Well
description: Open to anybody aged 60+ - our weekly Guitar Clubs are split into a Beginners Group (10am - 11am) and Improvers (11.15am - 12.15pm). Run by volunteer John, come and share your interest in learning or developing your guitar-playing skills! Booking is essential to gauge which group has space. Please bring a guitar if you have one (small number of guitars available for use during the session).

organization.name: Living Later Life Well Project
organization.description: Living Later Life Well is a community engagement project for people aged 60+ to reduce loneliness.

name: Harbour
description: Harbour is a space to work in the company of others and make helpful connections leading to the development of ideas as well as people. 1-2-1 Coaching is also provided to help you and your business to find direction and reach your potential.

organization.description: Oatridge Coaching provides 1-2-1 non-directive coaching to anyone about anything to help them to move forward, grow and develop themselves.  They host Harbour in various locations across North Lincolnshire which is a pop-up space for Co-working, Connecting and Coaching which at present is free to the user as it is fully funded by the UK Government.

name: Hatha Yoga
description:
Hatha yoga focuses on posture and breathing techniques, traditionally to channel vital energy source. In Sanskrit, Hatha translates to life force. 

The practice involves breath, body, and mind, and classes are 90 minutes of breathing, yoga poses and meditation.

The yoga poses help make the body stronger and more flexible whilst relaxing the mind.

The final part of the session is dedicated to relaxation.

Please check website for more details.

https://www.kirtoninlindsey.com/hathayoga

organization.name: kirtoninlindsey.com
organization.description:
kirtoninlindsey.com is a community website featuring information on all facilities, community groups, fitness classes and useful links in the area.

Kirton in Lindsey is a picturesque town in Lincolnshire and is situated approximately an hour’s drive from the cities of Leeds and Sheffield, and only 30 minutes from Lincoln.

name: Haxey Community Cuppa
description: Community Cuppa. Pop along for a cuppa, cake and chat. Free internet access and support. Advice and signposting to other services.

organization.name: St Nicholas Church
organization.description: Haxey Parish Church is an active Anglican church at the heart of the parish of Haxey, which includes the villages of Haxey, Westwoodside, East Lound and Graizelound. It is known locally as the "Cathedral of the Isle" being the largest church building in the Isle of Axholme.

name: Haxey Tennis Club
description:
Haxey Tennis Club is a small, very friendly club with two floodlit courts in Haxey Playing Field. The club has mid-week mixed doubles teams in the Gainsborough Evening Tennis League. Also on the playing front, we offer very high quality coaching and we organise internal Tennis Tournaments, and an end of season tennis barbeque. The club welcomes players of all standards.

Please note opening times on Bank Holidays may differ from those stated.

name: Health & Hijabs
description:
Welcome to Health & Hijabs where we’re as passionate about getting you healthy and fit it as we are about honouring your deen. 

In noticing the barriers faced by Muslim women when it comes to the world of fitness, New Beginnings wanted to help provide a suitable place to set and crush your goals like the fierce Muslim woman you are.

We believe in demanding a better future for Muslim women in fitness and creating environments where all women can thrive because whilst we may not act or look the same, we all share the same drive for great health.

'Empowering Muslim Females with the teachings of Islam along with easy-to-follow nutrition and workout plans, to take control of their health, not only to enjoy the benefits in this world but to have a beautiful Akhirah too’.

With use of the mini gym for children aged 2 - 8 years old.

organization.name: New Beginnings
organization.description:
New Beginnings Personal Training and Wellness Facility offer the highest quality services and treatments for mind, body and wellness.


Our services are provided by highly qualified personal trainers who are experts in their field and hand selected by the New Beginning's owner and founder, Stacey Greenfield. 


Feeling good is a complex issue. Health is at the heart of it, but psychology has a role to play as well, and we need to have that feeling of looking good.


New Beginnings brings together a range of services for mind, body and wellness to help our clients be fit and well inside and out. The best way to great health is to look after the whole body, not just the physical aspects but also the mental issues as well; as the saying goes "Healthy Body, Healthy Mind".


Looking after your health as a whole package is so important, yet it is something that far too many people sadly neglect.  Our range of services has been put together in such a way that many of them complement each other.


Our fully equipped personal training studio allows clients to work out in comfort and privacy. In addition this allows clients to also benefit from the expert advice of our personal trainers either with one-to-one support based on their individual goals or small group classes such as yoga.


Our New Beginnings founder is also qualified in nutrition and is available to put together the best possible programme to assist with weight loss, fitness issues and helping to create a health body. For those clients who have issues with food, we can assist with this. Helping you to create a more positive and healthier person both on the outside and as well as on the inside can give you the real boost of confidence that can be invaluable in both a professional and personal capacity. 

From counselling to life coaching, our highly professional team can help you to overcome whatever it is that is preventing you from achieving your goals.

name: Health Screening
description:
At New Beginnings “Our mission is to help our clients understand their bodies better, providing them with the tools to take control of their health and improve their long term wellbeing."

This Health Screening and Lifestyle Consultation is focused on helping you take greater control over your health and wellbeing, and includes the following:

Height

Weight

Blood Pressure

Resting Heart Rate

Lung Function & Peak Expiratory Flow Rate

QRISK3 Test

Basal Metabolic Rate

Total Daily Energy Expenditure

Calories Macronutrients

Body Fat %

Body Muscle %

Visceral Fat

Body Mass Index

Waist Girth and Waist to Hip Ratio

Cardiorespiratory Assessment

Strength Assessment

Posture & Flexibility Assessment

Add in our scientific and confidential dried blood spot tests to empower you with the hard facts to make informed decisions about your personal health

name: Health Visitor Development Reviews
description:
Within our family hubs, regular health and development reviews take place to support you and your baby. 

Our health visitors are available to make sure their development is on track. A great way to ask questions and talk about any concerns you may have within our hubs. 

Our health visitors and nursery nurses make appointments to see parents and their children at the family hubs, to complete child development reviews. These contacts are designed to offer support and provide information to you and your baby/child on a number of topics and also to review and promote your child’s development. Sessions currently run at West Street Family Hub.

organization.name: NL Family
organization.description: NL Family hubs - supporting families across North Lincolnshire

name: Healthwatch North Lincolnshire
description:
About Us

The role of Healthwatch is to find out people’s experiences of health and social care services with a view to making sure they are meeting people’s needs, and to call for improvements where needed based on people’s experiences.

What does Healthwatch do?

Healthwatch has the power to make sure that people’s voices are heard by the government and those running services. As well as seeking the public’s views ourselves, we also encourage services to involve people in decisions that affect them. Our sole purpose is to help make care better for people. 

In summary Healthwatch is here to:

  • Help people find out about local care. 
  • Listen to what people think of services. 
  • Help improve the quality of services by letting those running services and the government know what people want from care. 
  • Encourage people running services to involve people in changes to care.

Healthwatch was established in 2013 and each local authority area has its own Healthwatch service. For details of Healthwatch services in other areas, click here.

What are the aims of Healthwatch?

Our vision

Equitable Health and Care services that meet the needs of every person within our community.

Our mission

To give every person the opportunity to have their voices heard and empower them to play an active role in shaping services in their community.

Our values

  • We are proud to be independent, and not afraid to speak up and challenge decisions that do not meet the needs of our communities.
  • We operate a culture of transparency and openness, ensuring we are accountable to the communities in which we serve.
  • Our work is evidence based – led by public voice and need. 
  • We are collaborative, working with organisations that share our vision of equitable health and care services that meet the needs of every person within our communities.

How do we work?

Healthwatch is for everyone in our community – adults, young people and children. Every voice counts when it comes to shaping the future of services and improving them for today. Healthwatch will help people get the best out of their local health and social care services.

People often don’t speak up because they don’t think they can make a difference. We know that people can be unaware of the care and support that is out there. People can feel excluded from services and access to services and treatment isn’t always equal. Those who are least able to speak out will be heard through Healthwatch.

Every voice counts when it comes to shaping the future of health and social care, and when it comes to improving it for today. Everything that Healthwatch does will bring the voice and influence of local people to the development and delivery of local services.

Through our network of volunteers, working with existing voluntary and community groups, and our independent research, we can find out what matters to you most about health and social care. Together, your views and our expertise will help shape improvements for everyone.

We will use the information we gather to spot important local issues and trends. And we will carry out our own research into those issues that need more investigating, working closely with existing voluntary and community groups and the authorities.

Most importantly, we have powers in law which gives us influence. We will feedback what we discover to the authorities who have a legal responsibility to respond and use our findings to shape and improve services and feedback to you on the outcomes. This means you can be reassured that your views really do count.

How are we set up?

Each local Healthwatch is commissioned and funded by the Local Authority. In North Lincolnshire, the organisation who has been commissioned to ensure the effective delivery of the Healthwatch Service is Meeting New Horizons.

The Trustee Board of Hull CVS provides strategic leadership, promotes good governance and accountability on all contractual, legal and financial duties of Healthwatch.

Who manages your local Healthwatch?

The Healthwatch North Lincolnshire Executive Team consists of members with varying specialties and experiences; they support the core duties of Healthwatch; delivering our statutory and contractual obligations to ensure that our communities voices are heard by those who provide and commission local services.

To find out more about your local Healthwatch team, please visit our Meet the Team page.

Who supports the local Healthwatch team?

Supporting our Executive Team is our Independent Advisory Group (IAG).

The IAG are a strategic partner to the Executive team, bringing added independent lay insight and overview regarding delivery of the annual strategic workplan and contributing to safeguarding the probity and transparency of Local Healthwatch.

You can find out more about the IAG, please visit our Independent Advisory Group page.

What powers do Healthwatch have?

Under the Healthwatch regulations, local Healthwatch organisations have the power to ‘Enter and View’ providers so that we can observe how services are being delivered.

The purpose of the visits are to identify good practice that can be celebrated and shared with others, and to identify any issues raised by service users.

Please out more by visiting our Enter and View page.
pc_attendingAccess_additionalInfo: We are accessible in person at our office, through engagement that are shown on our social media pages, via phone, email or via the website

organization.name: Healthwatch North Lincolnshire
organization.description:
Healthwatch gives people a powerful voice locally and nationally. At a local level, Healthwatch North Lincolnshire works to help you get the best out of your local health and social care services -whether it's improving them today or helping to shape them for tomorrow. 
We do this by listening to people's experiences, comments and concerns around the health & care services they use, and ensure that these heard by those with the power to make change happen.

description:
The North Lincolnshire Healthy Lifestyle team brings together lifestyle support services in one place. This makes it easier for you to access help and support for a range of issues at once.

Our service is available via self referrals or referrals made through your GP practice.

Support can be provided by bookable appointment only, for more information, contact Healthy Lifestyles to speak with a member of our team!

description:
Our Help to Claim advisers can help you with the early stages of your Universal Credit claim. You can talk to them on the phone, online over chat or using our British Sign Language (BSL) service.

Our advisers can help you:

  • work out if you can get Universal Credit

  • fill in the Universal Credit application

You can read our online advice on Universal Credit at any time.


You can contact an adviser through our free national Help to Claim phone service. Advisers are available 8am to 6pm, Monday to Friday on 0800 144 8 444

Our national charity and network of local charities offer confidential advice online, over the phone, and in person, for free.

name: Henry Blofeld:  'Sharing My Love of Cricket'
description:
Legendary cricket broadcaster, Henry Blofeld, takes the audience on a charming journey through modern cricket, while looking back at the great games of yesteryear.

Henry has been close to the heart of cricket for more than 50 years.  He has seen the game grow into a hugely international sport, where franchises continue to have massive influence and more and more games are added to the world calendar.  It wasn’t always this way and Blowers reflects on how cricket used to be and where it is heading.

In his new book he explores the big shifts, innovations and challenges facing the game today, while looking back at his life and career, recounting his cherished memories of his beloved sport.  With his signature wit and insight, he compares the cricketing landscape of today with the cherished memories of yesteryear.

Henry began writing about cricket for The Times in May 1962 and in 1972 he started his long career as a commentator with the BBC’s Test Match Special. During his career he has written for numerous papers and broadcast for both radio and television for many networks around the world especially in Australia and New Zealand. Henry now tours the country with his one man show.

£22/£24 OTD

Tickets can be purchased via the Ropery Hall website, in person, or over the phone on 01652 660380

name: Herbal Medicine
description:
Medical herbalists make use of plants whose traditional uses are backed up by modern scientific research and clinical trials. Herbalists study orthodox medicine as well as plant medicine and we are trained in the same diagnostic skills as a GP.

However, we aim to treat the underlying causes of disease using plant extracts in addition to supporting you with lifestyle change and improvement when indicated.

We prescribe herbs on an individual basis alongside other medication and treatments you may be having. I have worked as a Medical Herbalist for over 25 years and this gives me a wide experience in treating both acute and more long term or complex health problems. Some people choose to combine the Counselling and Herbal Approach together so we are truly working holistically.

Please get in touch for information on services offered and for details of how to book a session.
pc_attendingAccess_additionalInfo: I offer appointments in person and online depending on what you are seeking help with.

name: HNY Perinatal Pelvic Health Services
description:
Roughly 1 in 3 women experience urinary incontinence (unintentional passing of urine) 3 months after pregnancy, and around 1 in 7 experience faecal (bowel) incontinence 6 months after birth.

One in 12 women report symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse - which is when one or more of the organs in the pelvis slip down from their normal position and bulge into the vagina.

These distressing issues can affect women’s ability to work, their sexual and social relationships, and their mental health.

Our Perinatal Pelvic Health Services will:

  • ensure all women are offered a self-assessment of their pelvic health as early as possible in pregnancy - and by 18 weeks at the latest
  • educate all women on the risk of pelvic floor dysfunction and birth injuries and preventative action they can take to reduce this risk
  • provide additional support to those at higher risk of pelvic health problems
  • reduce NHS waiting times and minimise administrative barriers to treatment
  • allow affected women to access appropriate physiotherapy assessment and personalised treatment.

Please visit the website for more information.

organization.name: HNY Local Maternity and Neo Natal
organization.description:
Neonatal care is the type of care a baby born prematurely or sick in some way receives in a neonatal unit. Neonatal Units are a part of hospitals which provide care for babies who are born prematurely (before 37 weeks’ gestation), with a medical condition which needs treatment, or at a low birthweight.

Having a baby (or babies) taken to neonatal care can be worrying, but the staff looking after your baby should make sure you receive all the information, communication and support you need.

name: Hobbies & Interests
description: We are a friendly, creative group of people with a common interest – a love of painting and drawing in the medium of your choice. We meet twice per week on Tuesday Evening and Wednesday morning. Generally these are untutored sessions although we do arrange for professionals to deliver workshops on topics of interest throughout the year. Where needed, members are always willing to share advice and encouragement. Why not come along for a free session to meet the group before committing to join?

organization.name: Scunthorpe Museum Society Art Group
organization.description: We are a very friendly and informal group meeting twice per week. All sessions are free-painting, untutored. Artists of all abilities are welcome and they are encouraged to paint in their favourite medium, while also giving them the opportunity to try something different. This is achieved by one-to-one help, internal workshops and more formal workshops by professional artists. We have a huge library of reference books and a quantity of art materials for members to access. Two major exhibitions are held each year, plus one-day pop-up exhibitions, where members can sell their work.

Imagine a life free of pain (physical, psychological or emotional), fear, phobia, anxiety, stress, depression, addiction, allergies, insomnia and poor lifestyle choices including weight management, smoking/vaping and other unhelpful habits.

The Home Library Service will try and match you with a volunteer in your area, who will be able to visit you and bring you books and audiobooks.

Your volunteer will be able to bring you books which suit your needs and you will be able to keep them for a longer loan period.

name: Horsing Around – A Sculpture Trail Around North Lincolnshire
description:
This summer, North Lincolnshire Museums invites you to take part in Horsing Around – A Sculpture Trail Around North Lincolnshire. Part of North Lincolnshire Museums programme to celebrate the 300th anniversary of the birth of George Stubbs. The trail has seen 20 horse sculptures ride into our area. 10 life size horse have trotted up in North Lincolnshire, including in our parks and outside our historic buildings. A further 10 miniature horses galloped to Normanby Hall Country Park for you to find.

Every horse has been lovingly decorated by an artist. Each artist has worked with a school or community group to bring their horse to life!

Download the trail guide here

Horsing Around - A Sculpture Trail Around North Lincolnshire - North Lincolnshire Museum

organization.name: North Lincolnshire Museum
organization.description:
Discover the history of North Lincolnshire at our free museum near the centre of Scunthorpe.

A visit to the Museum is a step back in time through fascinating hands-on displays. Learn about some of North Lincolnshire’s amazing objects and stories. Explore the geology, local history and archaeology galleries. Discover how that history has been shaped by the landscape. Families can visit Dudley’s Den, a dedicated Under 5s space.

With a changing programme of family friendly exhibitions and events for all ages. Families can join Dudley Bear and explore by taking part in fun filled activities and crafts. Learn about North Lincolnshire with trails, back packs and family explorer packs.

Admission is free.

name: Housing Advice
description:
Housing advice for tenants, landlords, homeowners and professionals.

How we can help

Contact the housing advice team if you have any questions or problems about housing. We are happy to assist tenants, homeowners and landlords with any issues you might have. Please note that we are not qualified to give legal advice. You will need to speak to a solicitor if you have any legal questions.

All initial enquiries will be dealt with by a housing advice officer. If an appointment is required, it will be made at the time of the call.

Self help on HomeChoice Lincs

The self help option on HomeChoiceLincs is a tool is for North Lincolnshire residents only. It will ask you a series of questions and then guide you through the different options you can explore to improve your housing situation.

Home or hospital visits can also be arranged where necessary.

You can also contact the housing charity, Shelter for free housing advice on 0808 800 4444

The Housing Advice Team Statistics [PDF, 158Kb] includes information about contacts, homeless preventions, homeless acceptances and temporary accommodation figures.

Duty to refer

The public bodies who have a duty to refer are:

  • Jobcentre Plus
  • social services
  • authorities
  • probation services
  • hospitals (as part of providing inpatient care)
  • emergency departments
  • urgent treatment centres
  • prisons
  • youth offender institutions
  • secure training centres
  • secure colleges
  • Royal Navy
  • Royal Marines
  • Army

What you need to know

  • You can refer any customer / service user you’ve identified as being either homeless or threatened with homelessness.
  • The customer / service user must give their consent to be referred.
  • The individual can choose which local authority they wish to be referred to, so ask them where they would like the referral to be sent.
  • If in any doubt, or if your customer / service user needs urgent housing assistance, please contact us.

If you’re one of the public bodies in the list above and want to refer a customer, please email: dutytorefer@northlincs.gov.uk. Please note, this is not a secure email address.

Useful information

  •  Shelter (Homelessness charity)
  •  North Lincolnshire Housing Advice Self Help

How to make a referral

To make a self referral or agency referral please use our online referral form.

Victor House

Victor House is a new facility that provides a psychologically informed specialist environment that looks to support rehabilitative and recovery approaches and focus on the overall well-being of a person, including their physical and mental health and wellbeing, their level of social support (from a partner, family, or friends) and their level of community integration.   ​

Promoting recovery and rehabilitation will include enabling access to housing, education, training, and employment alongside supporting people to find and participate in rewarding leisure and community activities.  ​

Victor House creates the foundation for person to be able to begin on their recovery from a position of somewhere safe to stay.   ​

No referral is required to access the facility and we welcome everyone seven days a week between 8am to 10pm.

Alternatively, you can ring the staff based at Victor House on 01724 297 760.

Address: Victor House, 22-24 Cole Street, Scunthorpe, DN15 6QS

organization.name: North Lincolnshire Council Housing Advice and Support

name: Housing Support & Outreach Team
description:
What is Housing Related Support?

Housing-related support helps vulnerable people to set up or maintain a stable home environment. It is a short-term service that aims to give individuals the skills and confidence to be able to live independently.

The Outreach Team work with individuals in North Lincolnshire who are street homeless and support them to find accommodation and refer to other relevant agencies.

What are the aims of Housing Related Support?

  • To promote independent living skills in a way that maximises the service user’s ability to manage and maintain their housing.
  • To increase service users’ confidence in and ability to respond to issues regarding tenancy related issues to help achieve independent living.
  • To promote positive approaches to health and wellbeing.
  • To promote opportunities for training, employment and volunteering.
  • To prevent homelessness.
  • To signpost to specialist services where required.

Where can support take place?

A person may need support in their own home, or in supported accommodation. The support might be needed for a wide range of reasons, and will be designed in partnership with professionals and the clients circle of support. Client engagement in the design of their own support will be aided through the use of the Outcome Star Framework.

People must be treated with dignity and respect and be enabled to maximise their independence by doing things for themselves.​​​​​​​

Support is specifically centred round the individual and not linked to the accommodation itself. The level of support will be determined through the assessment process and can vary between 1 hour to 3 hours per week.

For those needing low level support, maintenance and reassurance only, formal support may be closed but a Keeping In Touch Service will be provided so they have a continued link to support for reassurance.

What can you get support with?

  • Support around benefits.
  • Support to develop skills around budgeting, money management and dealing with debt.
  • Support to understand responsibilities as a tenant or homeowner.
  • Support to understand how to be a good neighbour and how to be better connected with your community.
  • Support to deal with landlords, energy suppliers, council tax, services linked to the home keeping an individual/family safe and well.
  • Support to access health services.
  • Support to access training and employment
  • Referrals and signposting to other services as required, such as money advice, legal advice, drug or alcohol services.

Is Housing Related Support right for you?

Housing related support does not include personal care, such as help with taking medication, washing or bathing, although if you have care and support needs, a care needs assessment will take into account your housing circumstances. This would then require a referral to Adult Social Services

Some information which may be useful to you may be found on the North Lincolnshire Council website:

https://www.northlincs.gov.uk/people-health-and-care/find-local-care-and-support-for-adults-or-older-people/getting-care-and-support/services-for-adults/

Housing Related Support does not provide assistance to carry out and complete basic daily activities that take place within the home, such as Cleaning, Shopping and DIY.

Who can apply for support?

Anyone who has an identified Housing Support need (examples given appendix 1)

Is there a cost to the support?

This depends on the type of service you wish to access. You will not be expected to pay for short-term services eg up to 6 months.

There may be a charge for longer-term housing related support services, whether you will need to pay for housing related support or contribute towards costs will depend on your personal circumstances.

How do you access support?

If you would like to access a housing related support service, you can ask a professional that you are currently working with to make a referral to First Stop, part of the Housing Advice & Support Service at North Lincolnshire Council.

Email: Firststop@northlincs.gov.uk

Tel: 01724 298339

Who is eligible?

Anyone over the age of 18 who is:

  • Assessed as being in need of housing-related support, through the use of the attached referral, consultation with fellow professionals and an assessment form.
  • Entitled to a means-tested benefit such as housing benefit or council tax benefit (for services over 6 months) or are in employment.

name: Humber and North Yorkshire Health and Care Partnership
description:
Humber and North Yorkshire Health and Care Partnership comprises of NHS organisations, local councils, health and care providers and voluntary, community and social enterprise (VCSE) organisations.

The Partnership is one of 42 Integrated Care Systems (ICSs) which cover England to meet health and care needs across an area, coordinate services and plan in a way that improves population health and reduces inequalities between different groups.

We work across a geographical area of more than 1,500 square miles and serve a population of 1.7 million people, all with different health and care needs. Our area includes the cities of Hull and York and the large rural areas across East Yorkshire, North Yorkshire and Northern Lincolnshire.

For more information on the Partnership, its vision, structure and services please visit the website: Humber & North Yorkshire Health & Care Partnership (humberandnorthyorkshire.org.uk)

Stay up to date with the latest news from the commissioners of local health services here: News and blogs - Humber and North Yorkshire Health and Care Partnership

Alternatively sign up for regular news updates by clicking here: The Humber and North Yorkshire Health and Care Partnership Weekly Bulletin (tractivity.co.uk)

organization.name: NHS Humber and North Yorkshire Care Partnership
organization.description:
Humber and North Yorkshire Health and Care Partnership comprises of NHS organisations, local councils, health and care providers and voluntary, community and social enterprise (VCSE) organisations.

Our vision
North Lincolnshire will be the best place for all of our residents to be safe, well, prosperous and connected; experiencing better health and wellbeing, delivered through our Community First approach. People will:

-enjoy good health and wellbeing at any age and for their lifetime
-live fulfilled lives in a secure place they can call home
-have equality of opportunity to improve their health, play an active part in their community and enjoy purpose in their lives
-adult smoking rates continue to fall and were less than the England average in both 2020and 2021. We will study this reduction and ensure that the pattern continues

name: Humber Tuneless choir
description:
Hello there and welcome !

My name in Debbie Rayner and I first joined the Tuneless family in 2020 when I took over the as leader and manager of Chesterfield Tuneless Choir. The legacy was safe in my hands and the choir is the happiest of places with a thriving family of members making a great noise every week. I have spent my professional life in music and music education. My mission is to help enrich lives through music making. I love the fact that Tuneless Choir has all the benefits of singing without the serious stuff! Although I am classically trained and have conducted many “serious” choirs, I would describe the Tuneless experience as simply joyous and one of the best things I’ve ever done.

Now I want to bring Tuneless home to the Humber too and share the joy of singing like no one is listening with you all. No auditions here … we don’t care what you sound like and we even welcome members who can sing! We don’t welcome Kazoo players of course … they just come anyway!!

We sing a wide range of popular songs of different genres, everything from Doris Day to Harry Styles, via classics from the likes of Abba and Queen. We sing along (with various degrees of success – Bohemian Rhapsody is always a challenge!) to backing tracks. We laugh, dance, have fun and do some singing! Only the last bit is compulsory of course.

Our home is at the Assembly Rooms in Barton; 3 Queens Street , DN18 5QP. There is plenty of free street parking on an evening and a car park close by.

We will meet on Thursday’s from 7.30pm – 9pm with a break.

Please contact me for further information- it would be great to hear from you .
