name: Papyrus UK
description:
HOPELINE - 0800 068 41 41

PAPYRUS Prevention of Young Suicide is the UK charity dedicated to the prevention of suicide and the promotion of positive mental health and emotional wellbeing in young people.

Suicide is the biggest killer of people aged 35 and under in the UK. We believe that many suicides are preventable.

PAPYRUS was founded in 1997 by a group of bereaved parents, who had each lost children to suicide. Our founding parents shared core beliefs that suicide is preventable, and that those of us with lived experience of suicide have a valuable and unique contribution to make to the wider conversation around suicide.

Since then, PAPYRUS has grown into a UK-wide charity with offices in north west England, south west England, West Midlands, London, Northern Ireland, north Wales, south Wales, and Scotland.

Today, we are a leading youth suicide prevention charity in the UK. Our suicide prevention helpline, HOPELINE247 - 0800 068 4141 - is staffed by trained suicide prevention advisers, who work with young people – and anybody concerned for a young person – to help keep them safe from suicide. HOPELINE247 is a free and confidential call, text and email service, which is available 24 hours a day, every day of the year (weekends and bank holidays included),

We deliver our suicide prevention education and training packages to thousands of people each year, to create suicide-safer communities across the UK.

We also press for change to current legislation around suicide prevention on a regional and national level.

The work we do centres around three key principles; Support Equip and Influence.

SUPPORT:
We provide confidential support and advice to young people struggling with thoughts of suicide, and anyone worried about a young person through our helpline, HOPELINE247.

EQUIP:
We engage communities and volunteers in suicide prevention projects and deliver training programmes to individuals and groups. This includes equipping local councils, healthcare professionals and school staff with suicide prevention skills.

INFLUENCE:
We aim to shape national social policy and make a significant contribution to the local and regional implementation of national suicide prevention strategies wherever we can. Our campaigning comes from our passion as individuals, parents, families and communities who have been touched personally by young suicide. We press for change in many places using hard-hitting and dynamic campaigns as well as presenting evidence to those in power so that lessons can be learned and learning implemented to help save young lives.

Hopeline information -

You can contact us at HOPELINE247 if you are experiencing thoughts of suicide and need support keeping safe from taking steps to end your life.

You can contact us if you have concerns for someone you feel may be experiencing thoughts of suicide and need support in having safe conversations around suicide.

You can contact us to de-brief after supporting someone with their thoughts of suicide.

Our phone service is open 24 hours per day, every day of the year including weekends and bank holidays.

Our text and email service have the same opening times, but we do highlight that this is not an immediate response service, and it may take up to 24 hours to receive a reply.

name: Peer Support
description:
We represent our members and their families at various strategic meetings across North Lincolnshire, including with the council, the NHS, carer’s support and many, many others.

We offer peer support via our social media channels on WhatsApp, we also offer all of the up to date information via these channels. Our newsletters come straight to your inbox throughout the year. We also offer coffee mornings, and successfully launched our tea time natter as requested by our members. We are able to offer support to families facing difficulties with SEND through advice, education and sign posting. Our members vary in ages, with children of various ages, but who are all experts by experience.

We host an annual SEND Parent Carer Conference in co-production with North Lincolnshire County Council.

We welcome new members of all backgrounds and our members are able to access member only events.

Please visit the website for details of events or contact for more information.

organization.name: North Lincolnshire Parents Forum
organization.description:
Welcome to the Parent Carer Forum for North Lincolnshire. We are part of Contact and the National Network of Parent Carer Forums.

Our mission is to deliver better outcomes for families living with special educational needs and disabilities (SEND). We aim to:

create a culture of participation and co-production across the education, health, social care and the voluntary sectors. This means that we are involved in all aspects of designing, commissioning, delivering and reviewing services as an equal partner.
empower our members to ensure that their voices are heard at a local, regional and national level.
inspire our partners by sharing good practice and knowledge.
Our vision is for the best possible opportunities and futures for all children and young people with SEND and their families.

The North Lincolnshire Parent Forum Steering Group all have children ranging in age from 5 – 25 and all of them have been on the SEND journey since their children were born. They have knowledge and experience on a personal level with various diagnoses and the practicality of the day to day life supporting children and young people. Each one of them is a volunteer and they dedicate their time to ensuring the voices of parent carers are heard by the services provided to our children; including the Local Authority, Schools and Health.

We welcome anyone to join as a member who is a parent of, or has other legal guardianship of, a child with SEND to join the North Lincolnshire Parent Forum. Our members join us at our official events, our informal social events and our joint parent and child events where you can chat with people who have the same experience as you, seek information and guidance with areas of concern regarding your child, engage with local professionals and also various workshops with national and international professionals.

Your Steering Group learns how services and provisions are working, or not, for your child and your family. They share information with members and also with the professionals who they meet with at the various professional meetings across the sectors.

You can fill in a membership form or join us at one of our informal coffee mornings where one of our volunteers will welcome you.

name: Peer support session
description:
Peer Support session is for everyone who wants to expand their social circle. You can come along to chat with our other members, volunteers, and staff or you can join in a range of activities provided alongside the sessions. Peer support is open every Monday to Friday from 1 pm to 3:45 pm. You can come along to chat with our other members, volunteers, and staff or you can join in a range of activities including quizzes, indoor bowling, relaxation & chair-based exercises, games on the Wii, and arts & crafts.

Refreshments are available for free including cups of tea/coffee or a glass of juice.

Please note that in order to participate in Peer Support sessions you would need to book an initial assessment appointment by calling us on 01724 279500.

name: Peer to Peer support groups online for carers of people with dementia
description:
Peer to Peer Support Groups online -  Carers who are members of tide have said meeting people, hearing and sharing stories helps with feelings of loneliness and isolation.

You can join us at our friendly get-togethers by visiting our events page.

Please visit the website for full details of online groups and support available.

organization.name: TIDE (Together in Dementia Everyday)
organization.description:
Imagine a collective of unpaid carers of people with dementia with the advocacy skills, knowledge and passion for making positive change for everyone impacted by dementia. Thanks to the work of tide, you don’t have to imagine. Tide works side by side with carers to ensure that their voices are heard. The foundations of tide were born out of the daily struggle that a group of women experienced in looking after family members with dementia. They decided that they did not want their experiences to become a reality for future carers. Out of this powerful commitment, tide the charity was born.  

Here at tide, we walk alongside carers. Every step of the way.  All that we do is grounded in the experience of the thousands of carers we have worked with over the years. We are continually inspired by the courageous people who come forward to add their voice to a growing movement. We see their confidence grow and lives change as carers realise the powerful impact of their voices. This is what motivates us. This is what keeps us moving forward.  

Whether you are a current or former carer of someone with dementia, or a professional working with carers, tide is here for you. Join us and let's make the world a better place for everyone living with dementia in the UK.

name: Peggy Seeger - 90th Farewell Tour
description:
Peggy Seeger, the grande dame of American and British Folk music, embarks on her last ever concert tour alongside her sons, Neill and Calum MacColl, in celebration of her 90th Birthday in June 2025.

Peggy has been performing for over seventy-five years and will showcase some of her best loved songs from across her extraordinary career, as well as new songs from her final album (out Spring 2025). Her songs remain uncompromising, and her wit and delivery are as sharp as ever.

Neill and Calum MacColl are superb musicians, sharing unique onstage chemistry with their mother. Expect whip-smart humour & family banter, blood harmonies and audience participation, alongside world-class musicianship.

This will be the last opportunity to hear Peggy in concert so do not miss this.

“Peggy Seeger inspires; as funny, feisty and angry as ever” The Guardian

“Peggy’s a vital presence, ready with a quip or a homily … Through their warmth, unity and ease of communication, she and her sons reaffirm folk song’s status as the bringer of news and its ability to address any issue.”   The Times

“Folk music with a raunchy wink; think Victoria Wood meets Dory Previn. Peggy imparts her wise and optimistic worldview with joy and a wonderful lightness of touch – a masterclass in storytelling through music.” Daily Telegraph

name: Peggy's
description:
Supporting families living with dementia, older age or frailty

We provide support for people living with dementia, older age or frailty in their own homes. We also provide day service provision for people living with dementia

name: Personal Alarm Service from SureSafe
description:
SureSafe's personal alarms for the elderly help older people to live independently in their own homes. Our personal alarms for the elderly call for help at the touch of a button. The elderly alarm pendant is pressed when you or your loved one gets into difficulty. They are alarms that can be worn on the body, either on the wrist or on a lanyard around the neck. They give you or your loved one access to help 24/7.

This can include following a fall, or a sudden illness such as a heart attack, a stroke or an epileptic seizure. They bring confidence and safety to the elderly alarm user, and peace of mind to worried family and friends. Everyone can rest assured that help is always available, quickly and easily, with a SureSafe pendant alarm for the elderly. Buying for yourself or a loved one? We can help.

name: Personal Coaching in Running Fitness
description:
Personal coaching over seven weeks available in North Lincolnshire for improving your running fitness, flexible and friendly coaching from a qualified UK Athletics Coach. Whether you are new to exercise returning to it after a break, injury or illness or planning to smash your personal records we can work together to understand how to run more efficiently and stronger for longer. Using drills, strengthening conditioning and a weekly running plan to achieve your running goals.

Please email me at coachingwithjb@gmail.com for further information and initial consultation.

organization.name: Coaching in Running Fitness with JB in North Lincolnshire

name: Personal Gains - Kirton in Lindsey
description:
Personal Gains is a bespoke facility nestled away within the former RAF camp site of Kirton in Lindsey.

Females of all ages and fitness abilities are supported, nurtured and encouraged to exercise to their given potential. Each plan is carefully implemented to suit and maximise individual 'Personal Gains.'

A singular and unique approach to exercise can be expected. Behind the name, lies the clue.

Whilst engaging in weekly exercise, expect anonymity and confidentiality.

Expect gentle progressive 1-1 tailored planning each week.

Look forward to a non threatening bijou environment within a happy, friendly and relaxed atmosphere.

Do not expect social media bombardment, accountability requests or constant vexing from tutor to client.  

Personal Gains prides itself in its warmth and welcoming of all females wishing to embark on a fitness journey that perhaps seems 'the impossible' right now.

Gym hire and equipment is also available for private use (uncoached exercise).

Please note booking is essential.

Please check the website for details on how to book: https://www.kirtoninlindsey.com/personalgains

organization.name: kirtoninlindsey.com
organization.description:
kirtoninlindsey.com is a community website featuring information on all facilities, community groups, fitness classes and useful links in the area.

Kirton in Lindsey is a picturesque town in Lincolnshire and is situated approximately an hour’s drive from the cities of Leeds and Sheffield, and only 30 minutes from Lincoln.

name: Personal Training
description:
The popular private studio facility at New Beginnings is always a welcoming environment for clients to have their personal workouts. This is the perfect health facility for those returning to an exercise regime as well as for new clients who are looking for a friendly and safe environment in which to improve fitness.


Unlike big gym groups and leisure centres, New Beginnings offers a much more intimate setting for sessions to take place. Clients can quickly relax and focus on their own goals, rather than worrying about whether they fit in or are doing it wrong with Personal Trainer workouts that are tailor-made to your requirements with one-to-one focus make for great results. The studio is also spacious and clean with state-of-the-art heating and air-conditioning filtering system.

organization.name: New Beginnings
organization.description:
New Beginnings Personal Training and Wellness Facility offer the highest quality services and treatments for mind, body and wellness.


Our services are provided by highly qualified personal trainers who are experts in their field and hand selected by the New Beginning's owner and founder, Stacey Greenfield. 


Feeling good is a complex issue. Health is at the heart of it, but psychology has a role to play as well, and we need to have that feeling of looking good.


New Beginnings brings together a range of services for mind, body and wellness to help our clients be fit and well inside and out. The best way to great health is to look after the whole body, not just the physical aspects but also the mental issues as well; as the saying goes "Healthy Body, Healthy Mind".


Looking after your health as a whole package is so important, yet it is something that far too many people sadly neglect.  Our range of services has been put together in such a way that many of them complement each other.


Our fully equipped personal training studio allows clients to work out in comfort and privacy. In addition this allows clients to also benefit from the expert advice of our personal trainers either with one-to-one support based on their individual goals or small group classes such as yoga.


Our New Beginnings founder is also qualified in nutrition and is available to put together the best possible programme to assist with weight loss, fitness issues and helping to create a health body. For those clients who have issues with food, we can assist with this. Helping you to create a more positive and healthier person both on the outside and as well as on the inside can give you the real boost of confidence that can be invaluable in both a professional and personal capacity. 

From counselling to life coaching, our highly professional team can help you to overcome whatever it is that is preventing you from achieving your goals.

name: Personal Training
description:
Personal Training sessions, tailored to your specific needs.

Weights for ladies, private Kickboxing or Taekwondo lessons, fat loss, food diaries to name a few.

We have Male and Female coaches.

Please ring to find out availability and to book a session.

organization.name: Twin Tigers Martial Arts
organization.description:
PROVIDING QUALITY MARTIAL ARTS FOR OVER 15 YEARS
Since we opened in June 2006, we’ve seen seasons come and ago. Timid students transform into warriors, students becoming trainers and a whole lot of changes at our venue. But no matter who’s training or what we’ve had to train with, our goal has remained the same – to provide our community of Scunthorpe and North Lincolnshire with the finest Martial Arts education we can offer.

We are blessed to have an incredible team of dedicated instructors including Master grades in both our key martial arts.

At the core of the team Master Smith and wife Lisa Smith work to maintain the family values of the school. Although several of the instructors share the Smith surname it is only coincidence.

Most of our instructors joined Twin Tigers to follow their own path many years ago and have since decided to share the life skills and benefits they found with others.

Twin Tigers is dedicated to developing our students, through a martial arts education.

Our instruction team work tirelessly to get the best out of each student. We ensure that our student’s progression is earned, never given. No matter the skill level or ability, we tailor our student’s experiences to secure the best Martial Arts education possible, for children, adults and everyone in between, we have a class for you.

We believe not only do we have the best instruction team in the area, we also have the best facilities by far

name: Pet therapy
description:
Paws4Minds provide pet assisted therapy and emotional support with help from Noodle, our therapy dog.

Dogs provide unconditional love and support. Dogs will listen, play and communicate in their own way without judgement. This is so important and can make all the difference if someone is unhappy or struggling with mental ill health, spectrum disorders or facing emotionally challenging times .

There are many studies that show the benefits of using therapy dogs, from mental stimulation, physical exercise and release of mood enhancing hormones that are benefits from interacting with dogs.

Paws4Minds provide aim to service for health, education sectors and businesses. We can also provide 1-2-1 support for individuals too.

We are a full time company,  so we are available during our business hours throughout the year.
 
We are happy to discuss your requirements and look to provide to support and help make a difference to people's lives.

To book, please ring, send an email or visit https://www.paws4minds.co.uk/ for more information.

name: Phoenix Programme
description:
The Phoenix Programme is open to any woman who wishes to know more about domestic abuse. It is a 12 week rolling programme - you don’t need to book.

Each group has a facilitator who is fully trained and has a deep understanding of the issues surrounding domestic abuse, it’s free and confidential. 

The programme aims to help women to understand the beliefs held by abusive men and the effects upon children, whilst helping them to gain the confidence to improve the quality of their lives and identify the local resources that can help. It is not about telling women what to do but empowering them to make their own choices. Those who have experienced abuse have little or no understanding of what has happened to them and it simply feels like a painful and confusing mess for which they are largely to blame; the Freedom Programme aims to start turning this around at the women’s own pace. The philosophy of the programme is based on research and outlines the role played in such offending by the pursuit of power and control. (The Westcliff session currently provides a crèche)

organization.name: NL Family

name: Poetry Flair Workshop: with Amanda Crundall
description:
Join talented and friendly local author and performance poet Amanda Crundall for a poetry workshop.

Immerse yourself in a morning of spoken word, stories and poetry, and relax and unwind surrounded by likeminded individuals in a warm and supportive environment. A cuppa and biscuits are always a must to accompany words, and both will be provided.

What to expect:

  • Sit back, relax, and listen to other's poetry
  • Getting stuck in with discussions
  • Tips for writing prompts and getting started
  • Shared experiences in getting published
  • Poetry exercise - starter for 10! (optional)
  • Open forum to ask questions
  • Where you can perform locally in the region and further afar

All this within an open and relaxed atmosphere and with a supportive host! For 16+. All welcome.

Follow Amanda and her poetry

Instagram: amandacrundallpoet

Facebook: She Wears Her Heart on Her Sleeve

YouTube: MandyCrundall

Amanda’s poetry collection. Heart on her Sleeve’ (2024) is available from Waterstone's, Brown's Books, Amazon and other retailers. Copies are also available at The Rabbit Hole Bookshop, Brigg, Loubie Lou's Cafe, Scunthorpe and The Wrecking Ball Book and Cafe, Hull. You can also purchase copies directly from Amanda her at her events.

This is a free workshop but places are limited and must be booked from Poetry Flair Workshop: with Amanda Crundall

To book, click on 'Register', complete your details and submit, to be added to the attendee list. If you experience any difficulties when booking or have any questions about the event, please contact library.enquiries@northlincs.gov.uk

name: Pony Club
description: Why not join our club and learn everything there is to know about horses. Pony club is a fun way to keep adding to your skills, learning to handle, groom, tack up and progress onto riding too! Pony club runs on a Wednesday after school, 4pm - 6pm and a Saturday morning. The pony club has 10 phases you can work through, achieving certificates, rosettes, and your very own hat silk once you pass each phase.

organization.name: Oikos Brigg
organization.description:
Oikos is a Greek word which literally translates to English as House, but more accurately - Home.  A place where you can be yourself, be fed, cared for and listened to.

Oikos - Brigg is a town centre shop with a difference! A unique not-for-profit charity established so that Christians of all denominations and none can work together to provide love and practical support for local families.

We strive to be a friendly, caring community where everyone is welcome and valued.

Put simply, our vision is to support our local community and as followers of Jesus, grow together, in faith, in hope and in love.

name: Public Engagement- Speak out about Health and Social Care
description:
Healthwatch is your local health and social care champion. If you use GPs, hospitals, dentists, pharmacies, care homes or any other support services, we want to hear about your experiences.

As an independent statutory body, we have the power to make sure NHS leaders and other decision makers listen to your feedback and improve standards of care.

Please contact the centre or visit their website for more information.

organization.name: Healthwatch North Lincolnshire
organization.description:
Healthwatch gives people a powerful voice locally and nationally. At a local level, Healthwatch North Lincolnshire works to help you get the best out of your local health and social care services -whether it's improving them today or helping to shape them for tomorrow. 
We do this by listening to people's experiences, comments and concerns around the health & care services they use, and ensure that these heard by those with the power to make change happen.

  • Velodrome

  • Javelin run up

For enquiries and bookings contact bookings.pods@northlincs.gov.uk or call 01724 291900 and choose option 1. Alternatively you can submit a booking request using our online form.

Scunthorpe
North Lincolnshire

name: Read On: Free Reading Support
description:
If you know someone that struggles with reading, North Lincolnshire Libraries offer a FREE scheme providing one to one support.

Read On is an informal scheme without the pressure of set class times, or achievement targets. Learners meet with one of our Read On volunteers at a North Lincolnshire Library for one hour, each week.

If you know someone that would benefit from the scheme that would like to become a Read On learner, please email us at library.enquiries@northlincs.gov.uk or visit the Libraries Facebook page.

If you would like to volunteer to support please email volunteering@northlincs.gov.uk

Deposit collections available on request. The books can also be used in group work and partnership working by pre-arrangement.

name: Recovery College
description:
Whether you are just going through a stressful time or started your mental health recovery, we hope you will find some courses that will be useful for achieving the wellbeing that you want.

Recovery college is for everyone who wants to improve their well-being, learn new coping strategies, or need some support with their recovery. We have a range of short sessions and full four to six-session courses including anger management, stress, anxiety, and self-esteem as well as courses for your general wellbeing like effective wellness tools, self-care essentials, and many more.

We also have some short courses for carers. For more information and to download the full prospectus please go to our website www.nlmind.org.

To make Recovery College more accessible we are offering hybrid session delivery - you can either join us in person or participate online via Zoom.

To secure your place please call North Lincolnshire Mind (01724 279500). 

These sessions need to be booked in advance, so please call us and get all the information you need.

North Lincolnshire Mind (formerly Scunthorpe and District Mind) has been providing mental health support in the region for almost 40 years. We are always striving to provide the best quality service for people who need mental health support. You can find more about our current services in 'Our Services' page.

Our organisation has a structure of trustees, volunteers, staff and service users. We are all here to help you with any requirements you might have.

We offer a wide range of services to support your recovery ranging  from informal peer support and activity sessions to more structured support such as our Coping with Life courses.

organization.name: North Lincolnshire Mind
organization.description:
We are here to help you in your recovery journey and whenever you need mental health support. We believe that everyone should have access to good mental health support whenever they need it.

Here at North Lincolnshire Mind, we have created a safe and supportive environment where we provide a variety of services from 1 to 1 Confidential Listening service to recovery-focused groups and social support sessions.

name: Reg Meuross: Fire And Dust, A Woody Guthrie Story
description:
Commissioned and produced by Pete Townshend and created by Reg Meuross, Fire & Dust – The Woody Guthrie Story is a journey into the heart and soul of one of America’s finest folk musicians. 

The breadth and depth of Reg Meuross’s material is unparalleled in contemporary folk: songs about forgotten heroes, famous names, folk legends, the climate emergency, tales from the kitchen sink and news from the world stage. If something needs to be sung about then Reg Meuross has a song for it and with Fire & Dust another important chapter of impeccably researched story-telling has begun.

“Reg’s terrific songs tell Woody’s life story with respect and affection, but also truth.“ Pete Townshend

£16/£18 OTD

Tickets can be purchased via the Ropery Hall website, in person, or over the phone on 01652 660380.

name: Relevant Person's Paid Representative Service (RPPR)
description:
Everyone who is deprived of their liberty under the Mental Capacity Act must have a representative. This could be a family member or a friend but if there is no one suitable it could be a Paid Representative also known as a RPPR.

POhWER’s RPPRs are qualified advocates who have specialist knowledge of the Mental Capacity Act and Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards legislation.

Find out more information about the Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards


What is the role of an RPPR?

The Paid Representative's role is to:

  • Visit the person deprived of their liberty regularly
  • Help the person to understand their Deprivation of Liberty Safeguards (DoLS) authorisation and how it affects them
  • As far as possible, assist the person to exercise their rights if they want to
  • Ensure any conditions attached to the authorisation are met, referring any concerns to the Supervisory Body if required
  • If necessary ask for a review of the authorisation, challenge the authorisation locally or if this is not successful refer the case to the Court of Protection. The Court looks at cases about people who lack capacity to make decisions.

Our RPPRs are independent from the care home or hospital and the Local Authority/ Supervisory Body. The service is free of charge.

How do I get support from an advocate?

Referrals are made through the local council. Please contact us if you need more information.

organization.name: POhWER
organization.description:
We help people who, because of disability, illness, social exclusion and other challenges, find it difficult to express their views or get the support they need. 

Our mission is to deliver high quality advocacy, information and advice services empowering people to have a voice and to make a real difference to their lives.

We are a charity and the advocacy, information and advice services we provide are free, independent and confidential.

As an independent organisation we are separate from the government, local councils and the NHS and we always put the wishes and needs of the people we work with first.

name: Respite service
description:
Lindsey Lodge has a dedicated nurse-led respite bed in a beautifully furnished room with en-suite facilities. The accommodation is bright and airy, with French doors which open out onto our beautiful gardens.

What is respite?

Respite is a way for carers to take a break from caring. If friends and family provide a significant amount of care this may enable them to have a break from caring, for example, to take a holiday.

Even if you don’t require a great deal of care from someone else, respite can provide a break from looking after yourself at home.

If the bed is booked many months in advance, we will always contact you before your admission to reassess your suitability for respite.

Respite is not intended to be used where you have a deterioration in your symptoms. In this case you may need to be referred to our Inpatient Unit.

Who is able to book a respite bed?

Anyone who would be eligible to receive services from Lindsey Lodge Hospice. You don’t need to be attending already.

Emergency Respite

We are aware there may be times a carer finds they are struggling but don’t have any booked respite. Subject to the availability of the respite bed, we may be able to offer Emergency Respite to enable a carer to have a short break.

How do I book respite at Lindsey Lodge?

You, your family or professionals involved in your care at home can contact Lindsey Lodge to enquire about vacancies, or book our respite bed.

organization.description:
Lindsey Lodge Hospice provides care for adults with life limiting illnesses and aims to provide specialist palliative care for day and inpatients to the highest standard, consisting of symptom management, emotional support and end of life care.

We provide a wide range of services including symptom management, physiotherapy and a lymphoedema service, as well as complimentary therapy, nursing and practical care, emergency care, end of life care along with bereavement and family support services.

organization.name: North Lincolnshire Council Road Safety
organization.description:
Who Are We?
North Lincolnshire Road Safety Team form part of the North Lincolnshire Highway Safety Department and work to reduce casualties on North Lincolnshire roads.
We provide universal advice, information and targeted interventions to groups that are high on the hierarchy of road users in the highway code alongside high risk target groups according to data analysis.
What we do?
We have a range of partners that we work closely with to deliver the best outcomes for our residents these include
Raising awareness events and Projects in venues across North Lincolnshire area.
NHS Midwife Services
NLC Departments including Children and Families including NL Family, 2021 and community Hubs.
EYFS Settings
Schools and FE providers
Safer Roads Humber provide training to Young driver, driving for business and older drivers sessions.
How do you get involved?
Watch out for our public events and projects advertised on social media channels.
Become involved with our partners in targeted sessions and provide us with feedback.

All enquiries : roadsafety@northlincs.gov.uk

name: Ruth Moody
description: It is exactly ten years since Ruth Moody last played THL, in what was a memorable sold-out concert.  Ruth, from Manitoba was a founder member of the acclaimed trio, The Wailin' Jennys.  Her collaborations with Mark Knopfler showcased her voice to music lovers around the world.  Ruth took time out in 2016 to raise a family, now she's back with a fantastic new album 'Wanderer' that chronicles her life over the last ten years.

Anyone experiencing mental health distress is welcome to contact Haven on 01724 279500. Leave your name and telephone number and one of our staff members will call you back.

name: Safer Neighbourhoods
description:
Safer Neighbourhoods are the internal Community Safety Team of North Lincolnshire Council

WHO WE ARE

Safer Neighbourhoods is the Crime and Disorder Reduction Department of North Lincolnshire Council and are responsible for contributing to the delivery of the Safer Communities Plan.

Annually our analyst produces a Joint Strategic Intelligence Assessment (JSIA) document which identifies the priorities for the partnership. The JSIA aims to provide an accurate picture of the current, emerging and longer-term issues facing the Partnership and shows performance against the priorities set out in the North Lincolnshire Safer Communities Plan.

The JSIA also identifies where the hotspots are for various crimes and who the offenders and victims are, enabling us to focus our resources.

Partner Agencies We Work With

One of the roles of Safer Neighbourhoods is to provide a link between agencies and work together to reduce crime, disorder and substance misuse. These agencies include Humberside Police, North Lincolnshire Council, Humberside Fire & Rescue Service, Registered Social Landlords, Police and Crime Commissioner, the National Probation Service, Community Rehabilitation Company and the National Health Service.

We also play an active role, facilitating responses to crime and disorder issues at the Neighbourhood Action Teams (NAT) which are held in each of the 17 wards of North Lincolnshire and chaired by the local elected member and attended by key members of the community. These are not open meetings to members of the public unless you represent a community group.

How you can get involved?

  • Start or join a local Neighbourhood Watch Group and get involved with the NATs.
  • Become a volunteer by helping leaflet drop in areas and get crime reduction information out in the community.
  • Share any crime reduction information with friends and family.

Need More Information?

Email:   saferneighbourhoods@northlincs.gov.uk

Phone: 01724 297430

Follow us on Twitter at - @SaferNhoodsNL

organization.name: North Lincolnshire Council
organization.description: Local Council serving the residents of North Lincolnshire

name: Sax on Sunday with Sumudu
description:
Snake Davis performs with Sumudu.

Raised in Scunthorpe, now London-based, Sumudu has been a natural performer from a young age, singing, playing guitar and piano and writing songs.

She made her TV debut on BBCs “Pebble Mill at One” at the age of 15, performing her own composition, accompanied by Snake on sax and flute… Their next meeting was when they both took part in a mega concert with Burt Bacharach and Hal David at the Royal Albert Hall. She now enjoys a successful career releasing and performing her own music, often touring with Van Morrison and working as a session musician for big stars and on film scores.

These days Sumudu and Snake often meet playing with Jools Hollands R+B orchestra or, even better, performing as a duo in Arts Centres. Expect classic pop, some original compositions and a touch of soul and jazz.

Ticket and booking details on the website.

name: School Admissions Team
description:
To apply for a school place in North Lincolnshire please visit the council website and use the online forms and links to useful information you need to know before you apply: https://www.northlincs.gov.uk/schools-libraries-and-learning/apply-for-a-school-place

If you want your child to move school (for example if you have moved house), this is known as an in-year transfer.

name: School Transport Service
description:
Your children may be able to get free transport to school depending on how far the walk is, any special needs they have and whether the walk is safe.

If your child is between four and 16 years old, they may be entitled to free home to school transport, particularly if they attend their local or catchment school.

You can apply for school travel pass applications or a replacement pass online and upload your photograph. If you are unable to make an application online please call us on 01724 297000 for advice.

Visit the council website for more information including secondary and college pupils and pupils with additional needs. 

​​​​​​​School transport and travel passes - North Lincolnshire Council (northlincs.gov.uk)

name: SCJC - Little Choir
description: The younger training choir caters for children from 3 - 5 years of age during term time. The choir is led by Jenny Trattles, whose passion for music education is infectious. The Friday evening sessions last from 5.30pm until 6pm, and are action-packed with singing games and rhymes. The songs are carefully selected to help promote skills such as keeping a steady pulse, performing simple rhythm patterns, listening for tone quality, and accurately matching the pitch of other singers. These singing games and rhymes are also excellent for developing early literacy and numeracy skills, as well as promoting social skills and building confidence. Children attend along with their parents, who are also encouraged to join in with the session.

organization.name: Scunthorpe Cooperative Junior Choir
organization.description: Scunthorpe Cooperative Junior Choir, providing opportunities for young people aged between 3-18 years to come together and sing.

name: SCJC - Main Choir
description: SCJC Main Choir has between 60 and 100 singers aged between nine and 18. The choir performs a wide variety of music in genres ranging from Pop, Classical, Gospel, and Folk. The repertoire is carefully selected to best engage young singers, whilst also allowing them to develop a sound vocal technique.  SCJC is an open access choir, meaning that no audition is necessary.

organization.name: Scunthorpe Cooperative Junior Choir
organization.description: Scunthorpe Cooperative Junior Choir, providing opportunities for young people aged between 3-18 years to come together and sing.

name: Scottish Falsetto Sock Puppet Theatre
description:
Scottish Falsetto Sock Puppet Theatre presents

Post Office Scandal The Musical 

Their 13th brand new comedy show, all done in the best possible taste. Honest! An hour of songs, sketches, socks and violence, telling the true story of the Post Office Scandal, and much much more.

★★★★ “A distracting tonic for the times” – The Scotsman

★★★★★ “Had every single audience member… laughing until they cried” – Edinburgh Evening News

 ★★★★ “The finest, funniest fringe comedy you will see in Edinburgh” – Everything Theatre

Post Office Scandal is the Socks’ 13th new hour long comedy show, following such Edinburgh Fringe hits as Socks Do Shakespeare, Socks Do Superheroes, Eurovision Sock Contest, Boo Lingerie The Socky Horror Show, and Minging Detectives.

Please see the website for booking information.

name: Scrabble Club
description:
Scrabble is the classic word game, make the best word you can using any of your seven letter tiles drawn at random. Your word must use a letter tile already in play on the board. Scores are given for letter values and are boosted by premium squares on the grid. Each game for 2-4 players.​

All players whether new to the game or experienced will made very welcome.

No need to book, just come along and join in the fun.

Check out https://www.kirtoninlindsey.com/scrabble for more details.

organization.name: kirtoninlindsey.com
organization.description:
kirtoninlindsey.com is a community website featuring information on all facilities, community groups, fitness classes and useful links in the area.

Kirton in Lindsey is a picturesque town in Lincolnshire and is situated approximately an hour’s drive from the cities of Leeds and Sheffield, and only 30 minutes from Lincoln.

name: Scunthorpe and District Choral Society
description:
A welcoming choir for anyone who can sing, or would like to try singing. Although the society requires no auditions we reach high standards of music-making under excellent direction.  There are health benefits from joining a choir and much pleasure from the social interaction.  

Join us on a Thursday evening (new term starts from 5 September).
pc_attendingAccess_additionalInfo: All are welcome to join and enjoy singing with others. Bottesford Baptist Church from Thursday 5th September

name: Scunthorpe and District Running Club
description:
We are a friendly club based in Scunthorpe, North Lincolnshire. The Club organises Club training sessions, twice a week, at Brumby Hall, Centenary Way, Scunthorpe. Club sessions involve a variety of different activities including longer, slower runs as well as speed and hill work. We cater for all levels of ability. Speed does not matter, the only criteria is that you want to run, we will make sure you are looked after.  

The meeting times are:-

6.30pm on a Tuesday
6.30pm on a Thursday

All sessions are led by UKA accredited and CRB checked Coaches and Run Leaders. All our Coaches and Run Leaders are club runners who are undertaking training and examinations in support of the club.

Couch to 5km 

We run three beginners courses every year for people that have never run before or are wanting to return to running after a break. We follow a couch to 5km programme and the groups graduate at the local park run at Scunthorpe with their 5km run. The courses are for nine weeks and are led by our coaches and run leaders. We meet at Brumby Hall Running Club, Club Room at 5.30pm to 18.15pm on a Tuesday night and Thursday night with a third session on the weekend.

5 to 10km Training

We run three training courses a year and this is for runners that have completed the C25K course or runners that are returning to running after a gap or just need more confidence in their abilities. We introduce a variety of training including intervals, hills and tempo runs. The coaches introduce the runners to drills to complement their training with strength and conditioning. The course is for eight weeks and are led by our coaches and run leaders. We meet at Brumby Hall Running Club, Club Room at 5.30pm to 18.15pm on a Tuesday night and Thursday night with a third session on the weekend.

Latest 5K to 10K course starts Nov 24.

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdLMcFzwYtrLkhdqSkaPK2O9gLB3_Z62ah8QwptOJYZip_tUA/viewform

name: Scunthorpe Central Community Hub
description:
Our community hubs are based throughout North Lincolnshire. They make it easier for residents to access information, advice and support, and take part in activities to improve their health and wellbeing.

The hub spaces are open to everyone. They are a central point in the community with support and activities for all – young and old.

The aim of the hubs is to:

  • improve health and wellbeing and outcomes for local people
  • develop skills and employability for residents, with a clear path to skilled jobs
  • create employment and volunteering opportunities
  • reduce social isolation by connecting residents to activities and services in the community
  • provide information, advice and guidance to local people based on individual need.

The offer in the hubs is built around the five steps to wellbeing. Easy-to-access programmes such as physical activity, social action, volunteering, health and wellbeing, employability and more are available. These activities enable people to maintain their independence, improve their health and wellbeing and develop a range of skills.

Direct help, advice and guidance is provided to meet the needs of residents and enable them to access the support and information they need to live safe, well, prosperous and connected lives.

Hub programmes

Examples of what is available to residents through the hubs programme includes:

  • bespoke IT training sessions to enable residents to take advantage of the social and economic benefits of being online
  • health checks for eligible residents as well as a range of specialist surgeries at certain times throughout the week
  • adult education and family learning sessions
  • general advice and support on council and community services
  • physical activity sessions to enable residents to get more active
  • health sessions around common medical conditions such as cardio-vascular disease and rehabilitation programme for people with chronic joint pain
  • social wellbeing activities that bring the community together such as healthy eating sessions, book clubs and knit and natter sessions.
  • a range of activities for children and young people which support wellbeing, including clubs and school holiday activities.

Facilities within the hub spaces include sport and leisure facilities, public libraries, digital technology, lifelong learning facilities, community kitchens and much more.

The flexible spaces are intended to support a range of community-led activity provided for by a range of organisations across public and voluntary sectors, who can provide additional health and wellbeing support. By working through these integrated approaches, members of the community receive joined up, quality, consistent information and support.

Community Hubs are located across North Lincolnshire within central and accessible locations in:

  • Ashby
  • Barton
  • Brigg
  • Crowle
  • Epworth
  • Riddings
  • Scunthorpe

To find the address of your local hub see the libraries and community hubs page

If you are feeling lonely or isolated, then please feel free to contact your local community hub on the phone numbers below. Or just drop in and say hello. You will always be given a warm welcome.

Contact

  • Brigg  – 01724 296776

organization.name: North Lincolnshire Community Hubs
organization.description:
North Lincolnshire Council connects residents with their communities through a network of locality-based community hubs enabling independence and wellbeing. 
The Community Hubs support residents by providing a safe environment to access information, activities, skills and services, and by providing the tools to enhance personal knowledge, confidence and a sense of belonging.  
The majority of North Lincolnshire residents live within a 15 minute drive of their local community hub. Hubs are located in each of the following locations Scunthorpe, Brigg, Barton, Crowle, Epworth, Ashby & Riddings.

name: Scunthorpe Central Library Breastfeeding Support Group
description:
A drop in breastfeeding support group run by trained peer supporters for mothers and their little ones at any stage on their breastfeeding journey.

Partners and siblings are welcome too. Please come along to meet other breastfeeding mums, share experiences or simply socialise. You don't need to have any issues or concerns to access the group but if you do we will try our best to help you or signpost you to the people who will provide the right support.

The group takes place in the children's library room on the ground floor.

organization.name: NL Family
organization.description: NL Family hubs - supporting families across North Lincolnshire

name: Scunthorpe Indoor Bowls Centre
description:
Scunthorpe Indoor Bowls Centre is a six rink indoor bowls facility in the centre of Scunthorpe. The only indoor bowls centre in North Lincolnshire, the facility offers a friendly and welcoming atmosphere for bowlers (and those new to bowling) of all ages and abilities. Take advantage of our no joining fee offer, saving you £20.

Scunthorpe Indoor Bowls Centre is open seven days a week and has a varied programme of activities on offer including:

Coaching sessions – Mondays 4.30pm to 6.30pm

The fully qualified coaches will support you and help you improve your game. Bowls are provided and shoe hire is available, so perfect for new starters.

Bowls drives – Tuesdays 2.30pm to 4.30pm and Saturdays 6pm to 8pm

The twice weekly bowls drives are open to everyone, just drop in. They’re a great way of meeting new people and trying out different rink positions in a relaxed and casual environment.

Fresh start sessions – Saturdays 8.30am to 10.15am

Fresh start sessions are designed to introduce non-bowlers to the game.

Friendly and league games

Friendly games are organised with other clubs in the County. These matches cater for all bowling abilities, and are fun, social events. League games are also played throughout the season with teams playing in the mornings, afternoons and evenings, and a Ladies League on Thursday afternoons.

For more information visit the Scunthorpe Indoor Bowls Club website.

Facilities

  • six rink bowling green
  • changing facilities
  • viewing area accessible for disabled users

Café

The Scunthorpe Indoor Bowls Centre Café is the perfect place to meet and enjoy a drink or meal with friends. The café provides a comprehensive range of refreshments including tea, coffee and soft drinks. The café menu also provides an excellent range of cooked meals at very reasonable prices.

Café opening times (during the main indoor season):

Monday to Friday, 9.30am to 3.00pm (last food orders at 2.30pm)

Membership

Scunthorpe Indoor Bowls Centre is pleased to welcome new members and visitors to the centre.

The winter season runs from September to April and the summer season from April to August.

The fees from September 2022 are as follows:

Membership fees

Joining fee

Final chance to take advantage of our no joining fee offer! When the offer ends our joining fee will be:

Adult £20

Junior £10

(Applies to new members or members renewing after 1 September)

Contact

Visit the Scunthorpe Indoor Bowls Club website

01724 280777

Scunthorpe

organization.name: NLActive
organization.description: North Lincolnshire Council manages a number of NLActive centres and sports facilities across North Lincolnshire. Some facilities are located on hub sites so the public can access multiple services at one location. NLActive also runs a community outreach programme and works with local communities to enable them to find a way to help their residents lead a more active lifestyle.

name: Scunthorpe Lions present Santa at the Museum
description:
Santa will be in the Ironstone Cottage on the following Saturdays:

30 November

7,14 and 21 December

11am – 3pm

Visits to see Santa cost £7 per child and each child will receive a gift. There is an option to have a printed photo with Santa priced at £3.

No need to book, just turn up on the day.

organization.name: North Lincolnshire Museum
organization.description:
Discover the history of North Lincolnshire at our free museum near the centre of Scunthorpe.

A visit to the Museum is a step back in time through fascinating hands-on displays. Learn about some of North Lincolnshire’s amazing objects and stories. Explore the geology, local history and archaeology galleries. Discover how that history has been shaped by the landscape. Families can visit Dudley’s Den, a dedicated Under 5s space.

With a changing programme of family friendly exhibitions and events for all ages. Families can join Dudley Bear and explore by taking part in fun filled activities and crafts. Learn about North Lincolnshire with trails, back packs and family explorer packs.

Admission is free.

name: Scunthorpe Museum Society
description:
​​​​​​Hello and Welcome!
The Scunthorpe Museum Society (SMS) was founded in 1957 to encourage and support an active interest in the North Lincolnshire Museum and Art Gallery. The Society also aimed to enable learning in a wide range of interests for local people. There are currently three sections of the society: Scunthorpe Museum Art Group, Local History and Archaeology Section and The Natural History (including Ornithology) and Geology Section.
Over the years the Society has part funded many activities for the North Lincolnshire Museum.

Who Runs the SMS?

The Society is run by volunteers with a Committee of Volunteers that develop the Events Programme and manage the governance and financial aspects of the group.

What Do We Do?

The Society offers a comprehensive programme of walks, talks and lectures that are open to all.

Who Can Join the SMS?

The Society welcomes everybody who is interested in the walks, talks and services that are offered. We consult with our members to ensure our Annual Programme reflects the interests of everybody so do come along to meet us. 

Do I have to be a Member to come to events?

No you don’t. You are very welcome to come to an event as a non member. 

Where are Events Held?

For inside events we meet at:

The Old Brumby United Church

Room 1 of the small Hall,

Ashby Road,

Scunthorpe,

DN16 2AQ

Accessibility

The venue has ample parking and is fully accessible including toilets suitable for people with disabilities or wheelchair users.

If you have concerns or queries regarding access or support needs for an event please contact us in advance and we will do our best to make adjustments that will support you.

Meetings that are held outside - full details of venues/parking and accessibility are released with the event. 

Fees: An Annual membership that gives you access to all events is £15 

Attendance at individual events without membership is £3 per event

Where to find more Information about the Society and Our Events -

Our website - https://keithandjune12.wixsite.com/

Our Facebook Page - https://www.facebook.com/scun.museum.society

Tel - 01724 762098

organization.name: Scunthorpe Museum Society
organization.description:
Scunthorpe Museum Society was created in 1957. There were multiple sections of the society initially but these have since reduced to three groups; Arts, Local History and Archaeology, and Natural History and Geology. Each group works independently and runs its own society but the Local History and Archaeology, and Natural History and Geology share the same venue to meet between September - April at Old Brumby United Church Hall on Monday evenings. 

Only one meeting is held in December where all sections come together for a social event. 

Please note there is a membership fee of £15 per year except the Art section who pay per meeting. 

Meetings are all advertised on the website.

name: Scunthorpe parkrun
description:
Scunthorpe parkrun is part of an international network of parkruns which provide a safe environment to run, jog or walk a measured 5km route around Central Park Scunthorpe every Saturday morning from 9am. It is a friendly, non-judgemental event in which to exercise with like-minded people and meet friends. The event is run entirely by volunteers who are usually parkrunners themselves though some volunteer just to be part of the event or to support family members who are taking part.

The route is mostly on tarmac or laid paths, though there is a section through the woods which is quite rough path which can make wheelchair access difficult, but not impossible. The route is marshalled to check participants are safe and there is a Tail Walker every week to ensure even the slowest do not finish last or alone.

If participants want to receive a time for covering the route, they can register at register | parkrun UK to produce a barcode which will be required at the end of the course. Individuals will be informed of their times by email and text and results are recorded on our website results | Scunthorpe parkrun

Before every parkrun there is a first timers welcome for our volunteers to explain the route and answer any questions at about 8.50am. Safeguarding is taken very seriously and there is a parkrun Code (which is a condition of registration) which must be followed. Taking part with a single dog on a short hand held lead is permitted as is running with a pushchair (but not both, sorry!).

Children under 11 must be within an arm's reach of a responsible adult and must not run alone at this event.

organization.name: Scunthorpe parkrun
organization.description:
parkrun is a free, community event where you can walk, jog, run, volunteer or spectate. parkrun is 5k and takes place every Saturday morning. junior parkrun is 2k, dedicated to 4-14 year olds and their families, every Sunday morning.

parkrun is positive, welcoming and inclusive, there is no time limit and no one finishes last. Everyone is welcome to come along.

name: Scunthorpe Video Games Club
description:
Weekly gaming sessions at Scunthorpe Central on Saturdays, 10.30am - 12.45pm.

The sessions are free to attend and are run by local gaming volunteers. Only family friendly video games including popular favourites Mario Kart and Super Smash Bros. No staff are present at the sessions as it is a volunteer led group.

No booking required, just drop in.

name: SENDIASS
description:
SENDIASS stands for Special Educational Needs and Disability, Information, Advice and Support Service.

SENDIASS North Lincolnshire is a free service for children and young people with special educational needs and disabilities and their parents and carers. It’s impartial and we give confidential information, advice and support in relation to special educational needs and disabilities (SEND) and related health and social care matters.

We aim to empower children and young people with SEND and their families with the information needed to achieve the best possible outcomes.

We offer advice and support on a range of SEND related topics.

name: Senior School Youth Hang Out
description: A safe space for senior school aged kids

organization.name: The Arc
organization.description:
We are a friendly well-being hub based in the heart of the Westcliff community and we’re part of Ongo, which means all profit we make is put back into the local community. 

Call into our cafe for a cuppa, find out about events and activities, rent a room, catch up with old friends, or meet new ones. We also have free wifi, a Post Office and loads more to get involved in.

There’s a whole range of support and training available here at The Arc. From our Employment Support Coaches and Housing Officers, to agencies we work with like Humberside Police, North Lindsey College and North Lincolnshire Council. So if you need training or support, come and speak to us.

name: Sewing Classes
description:
Have you been inspired by the Great British Sewing Bee?

Have you ever found yourself disliking all of the clothing and soft furnishings available in shops, wishing you could create your own instead? Learning to sew is a great way to become more creative with the garments and home items you own.

The Party Frock runs fun, relaxed sewing classes in the North Lincolnshire area. Whether you want to learn the very basics so you can repair and alter your clothing, to make the odd outfit here and there for yourself and your family, or to learn how to create clothing patterns from scratch using your own designs, we have courses throughout the year to suit you!

Please have a browse around the website from more information on the current courses that are being delivered

Sew With The Party Frock – Creative sewing tuition in North Lincolnshire

Our classes are run in 2 lovely local venues.  Monday evening and Tuesday morning at Grange Farm Community Centre in Scunthorpe and Thursday evening class in Broughton Village Hall.

We have monthly Sunday Sewcials, full day sewing classes! These are held at Broughton Village Hall once a month on a Sunday.

These sessions are slightly different to the weekly classes as there won’t be specific techniques taught. Bring along a sewing project that you either want some help with or that you just want to be able to work on without the interruptions of home. I will be on hand to help everyone with anything tricky. You will need your sewing kit, project components and sewing machine, there will be tables, irons and extension leads provided. There is also the usual haberdashery ‘shop’ for needles, pins etc in case you run out of bits and bobs.

This is a full day session so it will advisable to bring a pack up, although there will be a piece of cake for everyone, along with hot drinks, water and biscuits to help yourself to all day.

organization.name: The Party Frock
organization.description: Sewing Tuition

name: Shop Local Pop Up Market
description:
The Shop Local Pop Up Market is a monthly craft fair held in the town hall. It's aim is to support local small businesses in and around the Kirton in Lindsey area. Most of our small businesses are local makers of their own produce. 

We have art, textiles, jewellery, cards, personalised goods made to order, personalised stationary made to order, wax melts, bath and body products, perfumes, bath bombs and much much more.

We also have refreshments available with proceeds from our market and refreshments going to local charities and fund raisers.

We are a not for profit organisation whose aim is to bring the community together, help small businesses survive and thrive and generally support our local community. 

Please see https://www.kirtoninlindsey.com/popupmarket for further information.

name: Short Breaks Team
description:
Who are Short Breaks for?

Short breaks are for:

  • parents
  • carers
  • and others

with parental responsibility for disabled children and young people aged between 0 and 18 years old.

What do Short Breaks provide?

Short Breaks provide an opportunity for disabled children and young people to take part in fun activities. Our short breaks take a variety of forms. In addition, they include the provision of day, evening, overnight and weekend activities.

Where do Short Breaks take place?

Short breaks can take place in:

  • the child’s own home
  • in a community setting
  • the home of an approved carer, or
  • in a residential setting

Most importantly, they can help contribute to children and young people’s social inclusion and personal development.

Further information is available on the Local Offer website - SEND Local Offer | Short Breaks for Disabled Children and Young People - SEND Local Offer (northlincs.gov.uk)

name: Short Mat Bowls
description:
The short mat game began in Ireland and was later introduced into mainland UK.

According to the Irish Indoor Bowls Association, the story goes that around 1926, when a group of bowlers from the outdoor club of Victoria in Belfast were rained off their green, they retired to their Church Hall, Strand Presbyterian. To pass the time, they rolled bowls up and down the bare floor and someone suggested that a piece of carpeting might help matters.

And so Short Mat Bowls was born.

As gentle as this sport looks, there is real skill involved in throwing and trying to get as near to the jack as possible. Not least because right in the middle is a centre block that must be avoided at all costs!

Check link for more information.

name: Shout 85258 Crisis Text Line
description:
Shout is a free, confidential, 24/7 text support service for anyone in the UK who is struggling to cope.

To start a conversation, text the word 'SHOUT' to 85258. Our trained volunteers are here to listen at any time of day or night, and messages won't appear on your phone bill.

If your life is at imminent risk, call the emergency services on 999.

Please see the website for further support and information.

organization.name: Mental Health Innovations
organization.description: A charity pioneering technology to improve the mental health of the UK population.UK with the first ever, 24/7, free nationwide texting service.

name: Showman and Coole
description:
Through twenty years and a couple of thousand shows together in bands such as The Foggy Hogtown Boys and The Lonesome Ace Stringband, John Showman and Chris Coole have developed a deep and instinctual musical bond.  Their music lurks in a truly unique space that is somewhere on the outskirts of old-time, bluegrass, and folk. The songs of John Hartford, Hank Williams, Dock Boggs, and The Band share space with the fiddle tunes of Eck Robertson and Ed Haley. The duo’s original songs and tunes take in all these vistas and paint something both personal and timely. 

They have performed across North America and Europe at festivals such as Merlefest, Rockygrass, Winnipeg Folk Festival, Mariposa, Wintergrass, Gooikroots, and The John Hartford Memorial Festival. In 2022, the duo released two albums; “ Afield” a collection of old-time fiddle tunes, and  “Much Further Out than Inevitable – A Tribute to Some Music of John Hartford.” 

For booking information please visit the website.

name: Sibs - For brothers and sisters of disabled children and adults
description:
Sibs exists to support people who grow up with or have grown up with a disabled brother or sister. It is the only UK charity representing the needs of over half a million young siblings and over one and a half million adult siblings.

How it can help

Sibs provides support for young siblings (aged 7-17 years old), adult siblings, parents/carers and professionals.

Support includes:

  • information about disabilities or conditions
  • online advisors
  • news and top tips
  • online and face to face adult sibling support groups
  • events such as workshops and courses
  • adult sibling guides, sibling stories and eBooks

organization.name: Sibs
organization.description:
You're not alone!
Do you have a brother or sister who is disabled, has special educational needs or a serious long-term condition?
There is lots of information and vice available for you. Visit the website for more.

name: Silver Singers Choir - Living Later Life Well
description: Open to anybody aged 60+ - join our Silver Singers choir for a fun hour welcoming singers of all abilities! Come and enjoy a singalong to various music, have fun and enjoy meeting new people. Just turn up, no need to book!

organization.name: Living Later Life Well Project
organization.description: Living Later Life Well is a community engagement project for people aged 60+ to reduce loneliness.

name: Simon Evans - Have We Met?
description:
Completing the Trilogy begun with Genius 2.0 and The Work of the Devil, Have We Met? finds Simon standing, like Ulysses in Tennyson’s famous verse, gazing out over the moaning deep and the twinkling rocks and wondering whether to seek a newer world? To smite the sounding furrows? To strive, to seek, and to find? Or whether in fact, to put the kettle on, crack open the Hobnobs and simply yield?

Drawing on Joyce, Proust and the career of Philip Schofield to make sense of his own tangled past and possible future, Evans skilfully weaves comedy, pathos and narrowly averted cancellation into an unforgettable two hours of unique entertainment.

“A typically amazing show… Masterful really. There’s no one quite like him.” Dan Jackson, @Northumbriana.

“An incredibly heartfelt and, of course, bloody funny evening.” Duncan Wainscott, @folkyvale.

“Still ruminating on an incredible night of storytelling/ comedy with Simon Evans last night – real genius in the elegiac tales woven perfectly through the sharp humour.” Mike Rea, @IdeaPharma

“We saw you last night at Tiverton. A 100-mile round trip and worth every foot of it. What an amazing show. Humour and pathos. A rare and beautiful thing. We absolutely loved it…” Chas Newport, @chas_newport

‘ A Masterclass’ ★★★★★ THE SCOTSMAN

‘ Jaw-dropping’      CHORTLE

description:
Over 30 years experience teaching and performing in the UK and USA. 

Lessons in person or online via Skype or FaceTime. 

Teens to adults, beginner to advanced. 

Opera, Musical Theatre/Broadway, Contemporary. The choice is yours!

Fully Qualified and DBS checked.

name: Slimming World
description:
Slimming World is a weight loss plan like no other. Millions have reached their dream weight with our generous no-hunger eating plan. Add an activity programme that starts when the time’s right for you, plus unbeatable support, and you’ll soon discover the Slimming World difference.

No need to book, just turn up.

name: Snake Davis and Gareth Moulton
description:
The Snake Davis Gareth Moulton duo is an established act now not just an occasional thing any more.. The pair reckon Ropery Hall is the ideal venue for them. Mellow music infused with pop, rock, jazz and soul.

Gareth Moulton – Manchester born singer-songwriter-guitarist, Snake’s long time friend and collaborator in the Classic Sax Solos project and Heather Small Band, Gareth also sings and plays for Cutting Crew and Wang Chung and is one half of the touring play ‘Fly-half’.  His illustrious CV includes recordings and tours with Go West, Nik Kershaw, Jim Diamond, Paul Young, Chaka Khan and more.. Golden tonsils, sleek fingers and tales to tell…

Snakedavis.rocks  garethmoulton.com

For booking information please visit the website.

name: Snake Davis with Johnny Thirkell and Mark Creswell
description:
Snake teams up with long time cohort and best buddy Johnny Thirkell and their mutual friend, guitarist Mark Creswell, for an evening of gorgeous mellow music infused with jazz soul and pop.

Snake Davis is one of the most in-demand rock jazz and soul sax players in the world, widely known for his solos on tracks such as Lisa Stansfield’s “Change”; M-People’s “Search For A Hero” and “Moving On Up”; and Take That’s “Million Love Songs”. 

He has played and recorded with artists ranging from James Brown, Tina Turner and Paul McCartney to The Eurythmics and Amy Winehouse.

Johnny Thirkell is one of the UK’s top trumpet and flugelhorn players. He has played on hundreds of pop, rock, and jazz recordings (including 22 No.1 records) and at one stage was on at least one album in the UK charts continuously, without a break, for over 13 years!

In 2009 he had two consecutive UK No.1 singles with Pixie Lott, and his credits include Level 42, George Michael, Jamiroquai, Grace Jones, UB40, Cher, Tina Turner, Pet Shop Boys, Swing Out Sister and Lisa Stansfield.  

In 2015 he scored his 22nd No.1 with Bruno Mars’ “Uptown Funk”

Mark Creswell

Virtuoso exquisite sensitive guitarist, studied at Leeds college of Music with Snake and Johnny. Mark is well known for his work with Tanita Tikaram, The Suspicions and Burden of Paradise.

Expect beautiful music, fascinating tales, banter and opportunity for question and answer and challenges.

www.snakedavis.rocks

“Johnny Thirkell is maddeningly talented; funny, clever, handsome, the best damn trumpeter I ever heard, and the only man I know who can wear a beret without making you want to move to another carriage” – Hugh Laurie

“Snake Davis has one of the most passionate sax styles and simple bluesy approaches a-la-Sanborn heard in these isles for a while”.  TIME OUT.

“A virtuoso saxophonist”.  DAILY TELEGRAPH

“A brilliant sax player who could wail like the best American players, but was at his best weaving around slow ballads, won deserved acclaim”  BLUES + SOUL

“He doesn’t mess about”                 THE GUARDIAN                     

“Snake is a joy to work alongside. His musical skills have no limit, in fact he is as free as a bird.”             DAVE STEWART (Eurythmics)

For booking information please visit the website.

name: Soak & Stain Stitched Lampshades
description:
Inspired by the work of abstract expressionist Helen Frankenthaler, Hannah Turlington has created this workshop to bring together creativity and intuition.

This workshop will teach you how to make a lampshade using fabric that you have painted and stitched into. It will allow you to experiment and combine two, very different, processes to create the fabric for a finished lampshade to use in your home.

There is an opportunity to experiment prior to creating your final lampshade and have some encouragement and guidance from Hannah.

Designed for both beginners and those with prior experience of stitching.

£90pp

name: SOBS
description:
Survivors of Bereavement by Suicide. We support anyone who has been affected by suicide. The helpline is available 24/7 and we can offer help and advice, and are available to help anyone who is in need of urgent support.

For more information please visit our website.

organization.name: SOBS
organization.description:
Those of us who have experienced this terrible tragedy truly understand. None of us need to suffer alone. Together we help each other.

We help individuals support each other, at the time of their loss and in the months and years that follow. We aim to provide safe, confidential environments where people can share their experiences and feelings, giving and gaining support from each other.

name: SOBS Support Group
description:
Support group for anyone wishing to find out more information or receive support following a bereavement or suicide. Free tea or coffee is provided.

If you wish to join, please call the number above to speak to Nina who will be able to listen to your story and give more information about the group.

Why not join us at our friendly group that come together to enjoy the company of others, to have a chat and share stories whilst having a cuppa. There are also games to keep us moving and promote our health.

This is a very informal group and the topics of conversation vary widely and we would love to hear about you too.

We meet on Monday afternoons at Riddings Community Hub, Enderby Road, 1.30pm-2.30pm in the studio room. Free to attend and no booking required. We look forward to welcoming you there.

description:
Come along and join our warm, welcoming Reminiscence Group. We are a friendly bunch that enjoy discussing the past, present and future over a cuppa.

We love to discuss a variety of topics from the music of the swinging 60s, films from the golden age of cinema and disco fashion of the 70’s.

It’s a great way to meet new like-minded people and enjoy some stimulating conversation.

We look forward to welcoming you.

Please note the session takes place in room B09.

Please contact the team if you need further information or you require support to attend the session.​​​​​​​

name: Social Prescribing Service
description:
​​​​​​The Citizens Advice North Lincolnshire Social prescribing service aims to support people to take greater control of their health and wellbeing. Social Prescribing Link workers give people time, focusing on what matters to them and taking a holistic approach to people's health and wellbeing. They connect people to community groups and statutory services for practical and emotional support which can be anything from volunteering, arts activities, group learning, gardening, befriending, cookery, sporting activity to legal advice and anything in between.


Call our office information line 01724 870941 between 10 am and 4 pm on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays for more information.

organization.name: Citizens Advice North Lincolnshire
organization.description:
We give people the knowledge and confidence they need to find their way forward - whoever they are, and whatever their problem.

Our national charity and network of local charities offer confidential advice online, over the phone, and in person, for free.

name: Social Tea
description: Join us for some yummy food, to chat and socialise with other people and most importantly have some fun!
